The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.

div.p: OS OSSORIANVM, OR A BONE FOR A BISHOP TO PICK: Being a VINDICATION of some passages in a Treatise lately published, called ANTI-CAVALIERISME, from the impertinent and importune exceptions of GR: WILLIAMS, the Author of the Grand Rebellion: Calling himselfe by the name of the L. Bishop of OSSORY. Wherein Likewise, The Malignitie of severall passages in the said Grand Rebellion against the Parliament, is discovered; and that Question further cleared; How and in what sense Kingly Government may be said to be the Ordinance of GOD: So that it may indifferently serve for an Answer to that whole Discourse. By the Author of the sayd TREATISE of ANTI-CAVALIERISME.

q.hi: They make the King glad with their wickednesse, and the Princes with their lies.

div.p: London, Printed for Henry Overton, 1643.

div.head: A BONE FOR A BISHOP TO PICK.

div.p:
THe Country Proverbe is, that Good Ale never wants a friend on the Bench: Nor doth any notable designe of the Divell, against Reformation, or the power of Religion, ever want a friend, or two (for faile) upon the Episcopall Chayre. The Author of the Grand Rebellion (a title fit for Gr: Williams L. Bishop of Ossory, be it a man with a Vizard or without, and of his own procuring) ingenuously confesseth, pag. 4. of his discourse, that we scarce read of any Rebellion, but some base Priests, the Chaplaines of the Divell, have begot it Habemus confitentem reum: out of his own mouth, or from his own pen, we may judge him. For the truth is, that there is no baser Priests, then base Bishops, as there is no baser drosse then that which flies highest and lyes uppermost upon the mettall: nor is there any ranke of men under Heaven, which furnish the Divell with Chaplaines more to his minde, better instructed for the Kingdom of darknesse, readier either to sing or say masse at his elbow in state, then these. And very true it is, as this Grand Rebellionist affirmeth, that we scarce
read of any Rebellion, but some of these base Priests have begot it. He that desires particular information hereof, at least as far as concernes the Rebellions begotten in this Land and Kingdome, is desired to repaire to Mr. Prynn's late Collections, entituled, The Antipathie of the English Lordly Prelacie, both to Regall Monarchy, and civill unity: where he shall finde many Rebellions and mischievous plots against Kings, and all of them calling Bishops by that Name and title they so much affect, I meane, FATHERS.

And whether the present distempers, distractions, calamities and confusions, which shake the very foundations of this Kingdome and State at this day, amongst which notwithstanding our Hierarchicall Seer finds his Grand Rebellion, doe not relate unto his own order, as the principall founders and fomenters of them; I referre to the mature and impartiall consideration of all knowing men amongst us, that have not drunk away their Christian wits, or drown'd their principles of ingenuity, in the intoxicating cup of the Romish whore. That dangerous arrow of contention which was lately shot betweene the two Sister Nations, England and Scotland, do not the world know that it was shot out of an Episcopall Bow? And who are those that have sown the seeds of that most unnaturall and deplorable strife, now broken out into a devouring flame between his Majesty and his people, but statizing Prelates, who by the waters of their base flattery falling down so abundantly from the mountaines of their pride, into the channell of Prerogative, have made it swell like Iordan in the time of Harvest when hee overfloweth his banks? If men should set themselves to powre contempt upon Princes, and to undermine the Thrones, yea or the lives themselves, of Kings: there is no method or practise of a more conexive importance, of a more precipitate tendency hereunto, then by exposing and rendring them obnoxious to the jealousie of God, by making them his compeer's, in Omniscience, Omnipresence, Omnipotencie, &c. Which one of the Hierarchicall Classis (Dr. Corbet by Name,) late Bishop of Norwich) did in a publique Sermon at Pauls Crosse, not very many yeares since, investing Kings with all the Royalties of Heaven and
with all the incommunicable properties and excellencies of God. Men of this kind of addres unto Kings and Princes, and that through importune flatteries and Idolatrous admiration and adoration of Regall power, bereave them of all memory and thought of their being but men, compelling them to own and claime to themselves Prerogatives above the Moon, such as paralell, if not transcend, the Prerogatives of God himselfe: These are the men that cannot with justice count it any injury at all to them, to be look'd upon as the Grand Authors and procurers of farre the greatest part of all the troubles, miseries and mischiefes whatsoever, whereby either the Honour, Crownes, or Lives of Princes are indangered. The maker of the Idol, is sayd to be the sparke that kindles the fire wherewith it is burnt and consumed, Esa. 2. 31. And he certainly is the greatest endammager, if not destroyer of Kings, that See more of this Anti-caval. p. 14. 15. placeth their Thrones too neere the Throne of God, and that tamper with the hearts and consciences of men to adore I know not what an unknowne Deity in them.

The World needs not my information, nor any mans besides, that Prelates, especially of later times, have beene the Grand Corrupters of the loyalty of Kings unto God: and consequently by weakening their interests in Heaven, have withal weakened and shaken their interests likewise on earth, I meane in the hearts and affections of men.

And whether this Gr: Williams hath not beene hard at worke upon the same occupation with his Prelaticall fraternity, I appeale to the sweat of his browes, and the complaint of his eye-lids for want of sleepe, whilst his Master-piece of Grand Rebellion was in hammering.

It is no part of my intent to garble the bulk of his Pamphleticall discourse, or to sift out all the drosse and soyle therof, there being little said, but what hath (in effect) bin answered plus millies. I shall onely passe two or three briefe Observations, upon the generall carriage of the discourse; and then consider with what dexterity or successe, hee hath stormed the Anti-Cavalier, in those particulars of his Discourse, which a man would think troubled him, and stood in his way more then all their fellowes, because of his furious assault made upon
them in particular. But the man (I suspect) was herein more cunning then passionate: Hee made choice of those passages to give answer unto not which most opposed him in his way, but which he conceived would best take the colour of an answer & were likeliest to suffer an Eclipse of their light, by an interposition of some misty lines betweene the understandings of men and them; that so his Readers, and Party, apprehending some things answered in the Discourse, might by the figure Synechdoche, and out of their abundant charity, presume the whole Treatise to be sufficiently answered. It may bee this Philo-Cavalier is of the house and linage of that Ancient Souldier in Plautus called Thraso who represents his providence and prudence in War, thus: quà illi pugnabant maximè, ego fugiebam maxime:

q.l: Where Men were fiercest in the fight,
I made away by swiftest flight.

div.p: Certaine I am that where the Anti-Cavalier is strongest and neerest the heart of his businesse, there this Philo-Cavalier comes not neere him by 40. foot.

div.head: CAP. I. OBSERVATIONS CONCERNING The Discourse mentioned, called the Grand Rebellion in the Generall.
div.p:
FIrst, whereas the Author of this Discourse, pretends his Calculation onely for the Meridian of Ireland, and the Parliament sitting in his Episcopall See (as he calls it) at Kellkenny, pag 66. acknowledging with a counterfeit and gracelesse modestie, the Parliament of England to be above his sphere, p. 63. yet evident it is, by the spirit that rules in the ayre of the whole discourse; that the Parliament at Kellkenny was but the shadow; and the Parliament of England the body, that he would have sacrificed upon the service of his Episcopall See; and that they are not the Rebells indeed, the Popish Rebells in Ireland that this Gr. mainely brands with the odious imputation of Rebellion; but the best and loyallest Subjects of England, who favour the proceedings of the Parliament here, as just and equall, (being by solemne Protestation unto God lately made; deepely bound hereunto) The malignity of his intentions • n this kind are so virulent and strong of the poyson, that it eates through the vaile and covering of Kellkenny, and Rebellion in Ireland which he casts over it in severall passages of his discourse: and plainely discovers it's bent against the Parliament of England. See whether these lines be calculated for the Rebellion in Ireland, or Parliament and Parliament friends in England. Nemo repentè fit pessimus: But the wicked grow worse and worse: First you must lend, then you must give, if not, we will take: or if you deny your goods, we will have your bodies. So
at first, whatsoever we doe, it is for the King, &c. p. 97. So againe p. 68. it is well knowne to all the world, that whatsoever this good King hath Suffered at the hands of his Subiects, it is for the preservation of the true Protestant Religion, of the established lawes of this Kingdome, of those Reverend Bishops, Grave Doctors, and all the rest of the learned and Religious Clergie, that have ever maintained and will to the spilling of the last drop of their blood, defend this Truth against all Papists, and other Anabaptisticall Brownists and Sectaries whatsoever. In these and many other passages of His Pamphlet, quasi so ex suo indicio perit.

q.l: Much like a Rat, before he is aware.
He squeak's himselfe into a trapping snare.

div.p: By this observation it is evident, that though the man bee but a Diocesan Bishop, yet he is an Arch-dissembler, and metropoliticall Politician. He shelter's himselfe behind Kelkenny and the Paliament there, as his Bullwarke: and let's flie at the Parliament of England, hoping, that though God should prosper his owne Cause in their hand, yet Kelkenny and the Rebells in Ireland, will protect him from the sword of their Justice.

Secondly, that is considerable in the generall Carriage of his Discourse, that the bent of his fiercenesse all along is only (or chiefly) against his owne Fancy or shadow, and that hee either purely mistakes or willingly dissembles the state of the question betweene him and his adversaries. For all that hee beats himselfe, and wearies his Reader to prove in his Grand Rebellion, as appeares from the very Title Page, is this, That it is no wayes lawfull for any private man, or any sort or degree of men whatsoever in the Kingdome, for any cause, or upon any pre-text, to rebell, take armes, and resist the authority of their lawfull King: Which is a position, wherein hee hath neminem contradicentem (to my knowledge) certaine I am, that neither the Anti-Cavalier, nor the seditious Pamphleter (falsely so called by him, p. 97.) against whom notwithstanding he tyrannizeth with his pen as if he had borrowed it of the great Turke for the service have any thing in their writings, repugnant thereunto. If the
man had had a mind to have done any thing worthy of his Chaire upon this occasion, or to have convinced his adversaries of error, he should have grappled with this conclusion, & laid it flat on its back; that its lawfull for Subiects to defend themselves to the uttermost, against lawlesse Thieves and Murderers; or (which is the same) against those who without any lawfull Authority or warrant either from God or man, attempt by force to take from them either their goods, liberties, lives, freedome of Religion, or the like. But this conclusion, feeles not so much as the weight of his little finger. Or at least, he should have tried the dexterity and strength of his learning to make good this position; that it is not lawfull for a state, in tendernesse and truth of respects to the honour and safety of their King, and for the safety of the Kingdome to remove the wicked from about his Throne, especially being notorious Malefactors and Delinquents against the Laws: and further by their desperate Counsels and practises, apparently endanger both King and Kingdome. It is true, the proofe of this assertion, had it bin never so substantially made, would not have reach'd home, would not have concluded the unlawfullnesse of taking up Armes against those professed Sons of Abaddon those Cavaliers, that lawlesly and causelesly make spoyle and havock dayly of the lives, liberties and goods, of the Subjects of this Kingdome: yet, would it have come ten degrees nearer the maine Question in hand between him and those that are contrarie-minded to him, and vindicated the sufficiencie and learning of the man at another manner of rate, then by a long, tedious, and tempestuous discourse only to prove that the Sun is up at noon day, that lawfull Authority cannot lawfully be resisted.

But I perceive the man is full of Bishop-Craft: he saw that as well the impugning of the former, as the making good of the latter Conclusion were pieces too hot for him to handle, and therefore very wisely leaves them for others to burne their fingers with, if they please. But intending chiefly (as it seems) to abuse the judgements and Consciences of the weaker and lesse considering sort of men, and to weaken their hand in their way, he blusters and thunders, and armes himselfe with hell fire, to maintaine and prove such a conclusion,
which such men may easily think concludes them both, and yet in deed and in truth doth nothing lesse then conclude either. For to prove that Theeves and Murderers, or the destroyers of a Land, may not lawfully be resisted, because the Authority of a lawfull King may not be resisted, is as if I should goe about to prove, the earth to be a lightsome body, because the Sun is such, or that Gr. Williams is a Papist, because the Pope of Rome is such.

Thirdly, he that shall attentively reade the discourse mentioned, and narrowly compare place with place, shall find the Authour ever and anon prevaricating with his cause, turning head upon himselfe, full of inconsistences and firce contradictions, reeling and staggering, playing up and down, driven to and againe,
Nunc hûc nunc illûc, exemplo nubis aquosae.
i. e.
Much like a watrish Cloud, which somtimes hither
Is driven with the wind, and somtimes thither.
so that his Reader may much better, and more easily judge what his maine drift is by his Bishoprick, then by his Book. And the truth is, that they that have a mind to be his through Adversaries, need no other grounds to justifie the Parliament of England and their Friends, and the Armes they have taken up, then those that are positively layd down by himselfe. Nay that which is yet more, he affirmes and grants many things, which, if themselves were justifiable, would justifie farre harder proceedings against Kings by their Subjects, then any he so much as chargeth the Parliament or their assistants with, against the King. He affirmeth p. 67. that He that is entrusted, cannot doe more then all they that doe intrust him. Doth it not follow cleerly from hence, that the King, being the great Fiduciarie of the Kingdome, and intrusted by the people, can no more oppose them, then they him? Besides, how agreeth this assertion but as harp and harrow with that other, p. 64. viz. that the King is major universis, greater then all his People taken together? Doubtlesse he that is greater (in power and Authority) then all, may lawfully doe more then all.

Againe, p. 69. we have this fairly affrmed, that it is lawfull to recall a power given, when it is abused. Doth not the man (think you) hold the Deposition of Kings lawfull in case of abused power? especially granting, (as he doth, p. 65. that the power wherewith the King is invested, was, the Peoples, till they yeelded it up unto him Whether the man be of this judgement or no, I am sure his words are.

Againe, p. 55. we have (all in effect, and almost in terminis) fairely granted, which either the Anti-Cavalier, or the Seditious Pamphleter (before mentioned) contend for, in these words. But for private robbers, God hath not placed them over us, nor commanded us to obey them, neither have they any right by any law, but the law of strength, to exact any thing of us: and therfore we are obliged by no law to yeild obedience unto them, neither are we hindred by any necessity either of rule or subjection, but that we may lawfully repell all the injuries they offer unto us. I suppose the man hath so much ingenuitie (though it be not Episcopall commodity) as to abhorre to say, that God hath placed that viperous brood of Cavaliers in the Kings Army over us: neither hath he commanded us to obey them: therfore by his own cleare and full assertion, we are not hindred by any necessity either of rule or subjection, but that we may lawfully repell all the injuries they offer unto us. And this (I dare say) is the summa totalis of all the particulars in the Tract of Anti-Cavalierisme, if they were truly cast up.

Againe, when he saith pag. 103. That people have no better remedy, when Kings are evill, then to pray unto God, that as he hath sent them in his fury, so he would take away in his mercy; doth he not preferre the praying down, the praying dead of Kings, before the praying of them righteous, gracious, or accepted with God? Doubtlesse there is not the least touch of any so bloody a streyne against Kings, in any of the writeings so severely censured by him. Besides, he that recommends it as the best remedie that people have, when Kings are evill, to pray to God to take them away: doth he not hereby justifie the lawfullnesse of using other means also to effect it? There are very few things, if any at all, that may lawfully be prayed for before God, but that other meanes likewise may lawfully, yea and for the most
part ought to be used, for the obtaining therof. Woe be to Kings it this mans Doctrine should be received and practised home in the world. That insinuation of his p. 104. that a great part, (if not the greatest) of the Laws of this land, were obtained little better then by force and violence, compelling Kings to consent unto them, being rightly interpreted, doth not so much reflect upon Parliaments (which yet was the good will and intent of the Insinuator) as upon Kings themselves, who (it seemes) could not be perswaded or drawn to yeeld to the establishing of good Lawes for their people, without little lesse then compulsion thereunto.

I shall present you but with on threed more of this spinning, (for the present) which I draw out from p. 14. of his worthy piece: And in such (that is in a sinnefull] manner of assuming Government, there is just cause of resisting; and a faire colour of Rebelling against them, if you call it Rebellion, when men discharge their duties in defence of justice to oppose usurpation. Here is a blast of Doctrine that were it put in practise, is enough to shake the foundations of the Thrones and safeties of Most Kings now in possession; yea and to infringe and infeeble the right of their Posterities to their Crowns for ever. For how few Kings are there at this day sitting upon Thrones, some of whose Predecessors, from whom they derive their rights and Titles, have not assumed their government in a sinfull manner? If such a manner of assuming their Governments did evacuate their Titles, and made them unlawfull Kings, and gave the subjects of that Kingdome just cause of resisting and de-throning them; Certainly they who succeed them in their Thrones, can have no better or more justifiable Title, then their Predecessors, from whom they derive their Title-hood; and therfore affirme their Governments in a sinnefull manner also: and consequently there is just cause of resisting them, and men did but discharge their duties in opposing such usurpation.

Certainly if the Fathers or Grandfathers right for never so many descents, was no better then an usurpation, and they, as usurpers, might lawfully have bin resisted; the right of the Son, being none other then what descends upon him from these, can be no better then an usurpation neither; and consequently
there is the same justice to resist and depose him; which was to have resisted his usurping progenitors One of your sinfull manners of assuming Governments, is when the assumer murthers his predecessor; another, when hee deposeth him, &c. Did not WILLIAM Duke of Normandy, (sirnamed the Conquerer) murther King Harold, his predecessor in his Throne? except you will justifie one Prince in pulling out the throat of another and make all Wars between King and King lawfull. Now then by your divinity, William of Normandy, after hee had taken possession of his Crowne, might lawfully have bin resisted by the people, and they had but done their duties in defence of justice that had resisted him. You that have thus poysoned the fountaine, let the world judge how little the streames are beholding to you, you will never thrive by Hoggs, if you bring them to no fairer Market then this.

div.head: CAP. II. The first Encounter of the Author of the Grand Rebellion against the Anti-cavalier, about that Scripture passage, 1 Pet 2. 13. Examined.
div.p: THe Philo-Cavalier takes no knowledge of his Antagonist, for the first 47 pages of his Pamphlet, and upwards, but at the last line of page 48. hee lay's on with his Crosiers staffe after this manner.

And therefore though I doe not wonder that ignorant fellowes should be so impudent, as to affirme the King or Kingly Government to be the Ordinance or Creation, or Creature of man, and to say that the Apostle supposeth the same, because he saith, Submit your selves to every Ordinance of man for the Lords sake, whether it be unto the King, &c. Yet I doe admire that Buchanan, or any other man of learning, &c.

1. You may please to take notice, that the man was marvelous
well in breath and long-winded (halfe to a miracle) when he came here to grapple with his adversarie; for hee makes a period or sentence lasting two whole pages, and part of a third, between the rise of his sentence in his Quanvis, and the fall in his amen answering to it there are five dozen of lines (at least) full stuffed, partly with sense, partly with nonsense; as we shall see presently. This sentence (it seems) was built by him with like difficultie and badnesse of successe, as the City Iericho of old was built by Hiel, who layd the foundation thereof in Abiram his first borne, and set up the gates ehereof in his youngest Son Segub. 1 King. 16. 34.

2. As Peter and Iohn had neither silver nor gold, but gave the poore Cripple such as they had: So this man it seemes hath neither learning nor modesty, but such as he hath, hee gives his poore Brother Ignorance and Impudence.
But Sir, how ignorant I pray you, is the Anti-cavalier?

1. He is not so ignorant as contrary to all rules of Grammar, and principles of Rhetorique, and the common and known Laws of speaking and discourse, to place severall whole periods of speech, betweene a Quamvis and a tamen, relating each to other, as in the same sentence.

Nor yet 2. is he so Ignorant as to say, that the King is invested with the power of the people; and yet in the very same place to affirme, that the King is the fountaine of all power. This is your ignorance, pag. 65. of your discourse) not his. Surely if the power, wherewith the King is invested, was first in the people, the King is not the fountaine of all power.

Nor 3. Is he so Ignorant as to say, that the people freed Jonathan out of the hand of Saul, non armis sed precibus, that is, not by force, but by prayers. This is a feather of your Goose, p. 55. not of his. And the people said unto Saul, shall Jonathan die, who hath wrought this great salvation in Israel? God for bid! as the Lord liveth, there shall not one haire of his head fall to the ground. 1 Sam. 14. 45. This surely is no Common Prayer, to sweare or protest before a King that that shall be done which a man hath a minde to have done. I see Bishops have little skill in Prayers but onely in those that are Common; which certainly these of the peoples to Saul were not.

Nor yet 4o is he so ignorant, as to say, that the Ivie so entwisteth it selfe about the Oake, that the one cannot happily subsist without the other. This you say, pag. 10. of your Discourse: I cannot but wonder how you came to the knowledge of this profound secret in nature, that the Oake cannot subsist, without the Ivie twisting it selfe about it. I do not remember it in Aristotles Problems, nor in Theophrastus
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . But the comparison (I confesse) is very apt to represent the termes of relation between the two subjects you speake of, The Church you meane (which in your known Dialect, is the Praelaticall Clergie) and the Common wealth, have bin hitherto, and yet in part are so linked together, that as the Ivie intwisteth it selfe about the Oake, viz. to the sore detriment and impaireing and with perill to the life of it; so hath your Church circumvented and compassed about the estate and Commonwealth, to the extreame misery and sorrow thereof and to the imminent danger of the very subsistence and being of it.

Nor yet 5o. is the man you wot of so ignorant, as to affirme that an unjust malicious Magistrate, hath this ordinary power from God, to lay punishment unjustly upon us, which yet your ignorance inableth you to affirme, p. 26. what you meane by an ordinary power in this case, I confesse I know not: but certaine I am, that to say that any Magistrate at all, whether just or unjust, whether gracious or malicious, hath any power at all from God, whether ordinary or extraordinary, to lay punishment unjustly vpon any man is as like the sound of an empty tub as may be. And how much more to affirme, that our Saviour should say this unto Pilate? From which affirmation notwithstanding all your learning (it seems) was not able to deliver you.

Nor 6o. is he so ignorant, as to say, that hee that fighteth against the Kings army, warreth against the King, yet this you say, p. 97. which is, as if a man should say, that a Physitian that fighteth against the distemper or disease of his patient fighteth against his Patient himselfe: Or that he that seeketh to rend and teare the Ivie from about the Oake, endeavoureth to annoy and hurt the Oake also. Neither will your paralell instance relieve you at all against the imputation of this absurdity
except you can first prove by as sufficient testimony, that the Parliament is as much misused & led aside to its own ruine and ruine of the Kingdom by the Earle of Essex as it hath bin proved, that the King is misused by his Army and Persons about him.

Nor 7o. is hee so ignorant as to deny, that either Joseph in swearing by the life of Pharaoh, or the Midwives in lying unto the King, sinned. But whether your ignorance teacheth you not to deny both, let the 56. p. Of your booke be asked the question.

Nor 8o. is he so ignorant, as to prove, that Kings are acknowledged by God himselfe to be of divine Institution, because hee calleth Nebuchadnezzar his servant, and Cyrus his annointed. This is your demonstration, p. 48. If every thing that God useth or disposeth of for the fullfilling of his pleasure and purposes in any kind, should presently bee of divine institution the rage and malice and murtherous spirit of the Jews against Christ, should be of Divine institution too: For these were made use of and disposed by him, to bring to passe a counsell and purpose of his of farre greater consequence both for his own glory, and for the benefit of his Church, then any thing that either Cyrus or Nebuchadnezzar did see Act. 4. 7, 28. Kings may bee his Servants, and Monarchs his annointed ones though the institution of the kinds and formes of their governments, were from men. There is no man (I thinke) that ever thought or said, that those men, who whilst they were yet Subjects: were the servants and annointed of God, must necessarily forfeit these priviledges by being taken up into a Throne.

Nor 9o. (and lastly) is he so ignorant, as to say, that the rights and Prerogatives which are afforded the King by the Lawes of his owne Land come farre short of and are scrase the moitie of those Prerogatives, which the spirit of God hath in the Old Testament, warranted upon the Jewish Kings; and what the universall law of nature hath established upon all Supreame Governors. Your Pen blotted your paper with these lines, in p. 104. of your Discourse. I wonder what, or how many Prerogatives those should be, which the Spirit of God hath warranted unto the Jewish Kings in the Old Testament. It seemes they are like unto the Starres in the
Firmament of Heaven: the man can neither number them, nor call them by their Names. But why doth hee neither number nor Name, so much as any one of them? It may be he was afraid of an end of an old Saw.

lg.l: 'Tis poore Mans guise his Cattell 'ere to number.

div.p:
He conceives that he makes the better provision, to make them to bee had in reverence by men, both for their multitude and their glory, by wrapping both up in that mysterious silence which he hath done. The Inhabitants of terra incognita, are the goodliest men in the World. I doe not thinke that the man, notwithstanding his Censorian Rod layd on with so much severity upon the backe of ignorance, knowes any other Prerogatives warranted by the spirit of God unto the Jewish Kings in the Old Testament, but onely these and the like. 1o. That they should not multiply horses. 2o. That they should not cause the people to returne unto Egypt. 3o. That they should not multiply Wives to themselves, that their heart turne not away. 4o. That they should not multiply to themselves silver and Gold. 5o. That they Deut. 17 16 17, 18, 19, 20. should read the booke of the law of God all the dayes of their life. 6o. That they should learne to feare the Lord their God, to keep all the words of his law to doe them. 7o. That their heart should not bee lifted up above their Brethren. 8o. (and Lastly) that in case they turned not aside from the commandement either to the right hand or to the left, they should prolong their dayes in his Kingdome; they and their Children in the middest of Israel. If you will call these Prerogatives, I doe not know but the laws of the Land afford them all unto his Majestie in as ample manner, as you can desire them. As for other Prerogatives besides these, warranted by the spirit of God in the Old Testament to the Jewish Kings, I must be a debter to your informations, to attaine the knowledge of any: when you shall have fully informed mee, what, and how many they are, I shall bee the better able to give you an accompt, whether the laws of the land doe afford them unto his Majestie, or no; and whether those, which
these lawes doe afford him, bee not the mortie of them. In the meanetime I must, though at the perill of your displeasure, believe, that the laws of the Land doe afford unto him, and that in good measure, heaped up and running over all Prerogatives whatsoever warranted by the spirit of God to the Jewish Kings, and which the universall Law of nature hath established upon all Supreame Governors. But

By all these particulars, and many more like to them, that might be added it fully appeares, that the Anti-Cavalier hath not so monopoliz'd the commodity of ignorance, but that the Philo-Cavalier hath much of it lying upon his hand also. And the truth is, that notwithstanding by his severe exclamation against ignorance, he insinuats himselfe a choyce vessell of learning and knowledge: yet there are more then a few in the world, who know that farre the greatest part of a Bishops estate in learning, is ordinarily put into two bags; the treasure of the on being a heap of sayings and sentences gathered by the hand of an Index, out of authors, for the flattering of Princes: the treasure of the other, a like collection for the reparation and maintenance of the Episcopall Chayre. Take them out of these two Theames, they are (for the most part) like pisces in arido, quite out of their Element.

And that this Bishop by name, makes treasure and very precious substance of such collections as we speak of is evident from hence; because he layes them up with that extraordinary carefullnesse and intensnesse of mind, wherewith covetous old men are wont to lay up their gold. Himselfe confesseth in his Epistle to the Reader, that when he composed his Grand Rebellion, he had not his bookes about him: which plainely shewes, that those allegations and sentences from Authors, which are (almost) without end; (I am sure to no good end) heaped up in his Discourse, kept his heart company very neerely, and had double and treble care and cost bestowed upon them in their laying up. Otherwise, it is little lesse then an incredibility, that a man should carry such vast multitudes of other mens sayings verbatim in his head, except his heart were deep in the cōfedracy also. I do not believe that he remembers, or is able to say by rote, as much more; out of all
the Authors or bookes that ever he read. Therefore though he had not his bookes about him; yet he had the best part of his estate in learning about him, his Conn'd sentences for the undoeing of Kings.

But 2o. he is so advanced in choller against the Anti-Cavalier, that hee is not satisfied with powring out the contempt of Ignorance upon him, but further to grind his name and reputation to powder; he arraignes him at the Barre of his consistory for the foule sinne of Impudence also. I see it's ill halting before a Cripple: (however;) the common saying is, set a Thiefe to take a Thiefe. The man it seemes is so extreamely well experienced in the point of impudence; that he is able to discerne it where it is not, yea where there is not the least colour nor appearance of it. For all that he chargeth him with to make good his sore inditement, is that hee affirmes, The King or Kingly government, to be the ordinance, credtion, or creature of man: and, that the Apostle supposeth the same, because be saith submit, &c. All which amounts to no more, then to what himselfe granteth, and affirmeth immediatly, saying, that he (the Anti-Cavalier) might well understand (which I presume he very well doth) that the same act; is often ascribed as well to the mediate, as immediate agent. &c. So then suppose man to be but the mediate agent in, or about; the Creation of Kingly Government (which himselfe here supposeth) and God the immediate, (cujus contrarium verum est) yet may this creation, by his owne rule be as well ascribed to man, the mediate, as to God the immediate Agent, So that the height of his evidence; to make good both those hainous crimes, of ignorance and impudence, against the Anti Cavalier amounts to no more then this, that the Anti-Cavalier, hath no more learning or ingenuity in him, then to be of a Bishops judgement.

But Sir, give me leave to tell you that if a man would be so ill minded towards you, as to charge you with impudence, your Grand Rebellion would in many passages of it justifie the accusation to your face. For,

1o doe you not p. 68. Fome out your owne shame in these words? It is well known to all the World, that whatsoever this good King hath suffered (speaking of His Majestie) at the hands of his
Subjects, it is for preserving the true Protestant Religion, of the established lawes of this Kingdome, &c. Surely you have a very lax, wide, and Cathedrall conscience, or else such a prodigious and shamelesse monster of untruth could never have bin conceived there. If you had onely said, that it had bin suspected, or partly believed in the World, that the King hath suffered for those reasons you mention, it had bin a pretty streine of impudence, except you equivocate, and by the World, meane the World Malignant only. For in all the World besides, I know not the least touch of any suspition this way, but discover a full satisfaction to the contrary, on every hand. Nay in the Malignant World it selfe, I verily believe, that it is rather said and pretended then believed. But that which is not so much as thought, or suspected in the World, you strein courtesie both with your conscience and your forehead at once, to affirme, that it is knowne, and that not simply to the World, but, to All the World; Nay, as if you were up upon your tiptoe's to be aut Caesar, aut nullus, in point of impudence, you advance yet higher and say, that it is WELL KNOWNE to all the World. A man would thinke by such a deportment of your Conscience and Pen as this is, that you had taken your solemne leave of modesty, shamefastnesse and truth, and never meant to see their faces, or to have to do with them more. And to make your Conscience leave muttering and lingering after them you seale up your resolution in this kind, with another egge of the same Bird, p. 105. towards the end of your Discourse, where you give one tumble more in the same mire, affirming that the King suffereth all for the protection of Gods service, as it was established in the purest time of Reformation, and for the preservation of our lawes from any corrupt interpretation, or arbitrary invasion upon them, &c. The man (questionlesse) hath very lately (as if hee had quite forgotten his devotions to the Virgin Mary) Sacrificed to the Goddesse 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and is now,

lg.l: —Functus que sacris, et potus, et exlex
High drunken and of lawlesse guise.

div.p: I wonder what Crotchet hath fallen in conjunction with the Rochet to inspire the man with any such notion or conceit, that the King should suffer for the protection of Gods Service, or for the preservation of our laws from any corrupt interpretation, &c. Doth hee not make himselfe greater then the Parliament it selfe, in taking upon him to know the reasons and motives upon which they have advanced the forces now on foot, better then themselves? Or have they ever declared any such ground of those proceedings of theirs, which (it seemes by this Counsellor of state) are troublesome unto the King or as he suggesteth. Surely he hath plowed with some malicious or mad Heifer, to make such an interpretation of so easie a riddle. If the retinue of Jim and Ojim about his Majesties person, those hairy Apostates from humanity it selfe, be in the Bishops judgment, the service of God; well may he say, that the King suffers for the protection of the service of God. Or if the ruine and destruction of the Land by those walking sacks of blood, the Cavaliers, be the preservation of our laws from corrupt interpretation, it is somewhat a tolerable conjecture, to thinke the King may suffer for it. But if by the service of God he meanes either the truth of Religion, purity of his worship, or the like; and by preservation of the laws from corrupt interpretations, any such thing as the knowne signification of the words import; hee might with farre lesse disparagement to himselfe in point of reason, wit, and honesty, have affirmed, that the King suffers for not making the Sun to shine, or the Winds to blow when the Parliament would have him.

2o. If that saying of yours, p. 29. viz. That a King hath power & Authority to doe what he pleaseth, were presented to the Lady Modestie, I believe shee would blush at it, and not own it. Nor would any man that hath not his forehead fenc'd with Iron and Brasse, ever have adventured his reputation abroad in the world, in such a rotten bottome. Who ever gave a King power and Authoritie to doe what he pleaseth, God, or Man, except it be those enemies both of God and Man, I meane the Lords of the Chayre? Quod libet, licet, was an abhorring and hissing even amongst the Heathen.

3o. What fellowship, or communion, either with modeyst or
truth, hath that saying of yours, p. 101. that both the Parliament forces in England, and the Rebells in Ireland, make little difference. betwene Papist and Protestant, the well affected and disaffected: and that the estates of both, is the thing that they thirst after?

And yet as if you had not been shamelesse enough in your affirmation, you seale it up, with this triumphant Epiphonema; Haud ignota Cano. I see how ever the World goes, yet Bishops will be merry and sing.

I confesse the Parliament Forces, in the judgement of many, make too little difference in one respect, between Papist and Protestant; the well affected and disaffected; they shew more of the favour and forbearance, which they expresse towards the well affected, to Papists and disaffected, then their share comes to. But to thirst after the estates either of the one or of the other, is the disease that reigneth amongst your Legions: if there bee a sprinkling of it amongst the Parliament forces, I feare so much the more a Partie of yours amongst them. But (I see) it doth the man good at the heart, to make the Parliament forces in England; and Rebells in Ireland to draw in the same yoke of obloquy and reproach together.

In the meane time, these ejaculations from the Philo-Cavalier, with many more like unto them that bear them company in his booke, are sufficient to satisfie any reasonable man, that the Anti-Cavalier, is neither so ignorant, nor so impudent, but that he hath his Peeres, yea and superiors too in both, and that amongst those Cherubims and Seraphims themselves, who would so faine recover their lost Heaven in PARLIAMENT.

How sleight the ailement of the man is, to make these hideous outcries of ignorance and impudence against the Anti-Cavalier, was formerly touched: His grievement onely is, that he affirmes the King or Kingly Government to be the ordinance or creation of man, and that the Apostle supposeth the same. The man surely is besides himselfe, to fall so heavy upon another, for saying onely that which himselfe saith. In this expression of himselfe, the Anti-Cavalier determineth nothing either for or against any particular sence or consideration, in which the King or Kingly Government, may be called the creation of Man. And himself expressely, grants (not many lines after) that there is a sence, which he call's secondary or demonstrative, wherein the power and authority of Kings, is as S t. Peter calleth it, the ordinance of man. Hee that affirmeth Gregory, or Griffith Williams, (or whatever the name of the Hobgoblin, Gr. bee) to be an Irish Bishop, doth not deny him his Bishoprick of Ossory. Nor doth he that saith, he is worthy to bee punished for his Grand Rebellion, deny but that hee is worthy to lose his Priest-hood for it. Generall and indefinite sayings, do not
at all contradict particulars that are subordinate to them.

Well, but though the Anti-Cavalier say nothing in this passage contrary to him, yet hee doth not speake out, as hee would have him; he is jealous of him that hee meanes contrary to him; and that when he affirmes Kingly Government to be the creation of man, his intent is, to exclude it from being the ordinance of God, at least from being the ordinance of God in the sence Paramount which hath bin consecrated by the order of Bishops. But,

Might he not aswell fall foule upon St Peter for speaking no otherwise then the Anti-Cavalier doth, as upon the Anti-Cavalier for speaking as St Peter doth? St, Peter plainly supposeth the King to be the creature or ordinance of man; but whether he meanes primarily or secondarily, he expresseth himselfe no more then the other. But the man (its like) is more inclineable to have a good opinion of St Peter, and to befriend him in his thoughts, for the See of Romes sake, which claim's speciall interest in this Apostle, then he is of the Anti-Cavalier, whose loyalty to that Chaire (I perceive) hee much suspects.

But however it be somewhat an hard measure to be attainted as an ignorant and impudent fellow, onely upon suspition that a man will not conforme his judgement and conscience to a Bishops distinction; yet let the matter of fact bee confessed and acknowledged, and the Justice of it argued a little, and insisted upon.
The difference then betweene the two combatants, as touching the point in hand, consists in these two particulars.
1o. The Bishop affirmes, that God was unto David and Saul, and is to all other Kings, the immediate giver of their Kingdomes unto them. This the Anti-Cavalier deny's.

2o. The Bishop affirmes, the power and authority of Kings to be originally and primarily the ordinance of God. This his Antagonist craves leave to explaine (as he hath done, p. 5. & 6. Of his Anti Cavalierisme) or else to deny.

For the former; me thinkes that a very few words should serve to bring forth the truth into a cleere and perfect light between them. If God was the immediate giver of their Kingdoms, unto Saul and David, and the people the mediate, then the people were before God in the donation of them unto them, and God onely interven'd to second, ratifie and accomplish the donation of the people.

Every freshman knowes, that the immediate agent or cause of any thing, is the last and lowest in the subordination; and that which produceth the effect without the intervention of any other: and that all the rest, that have precedency therein, are mediate or remote. Therefore if God was the immediate giver of Sauls or Davids Kingdome, and the people the mediate, the people made use of God and not God of the people, actually to invest and inthrone them.

Besides, evident it is, that Gods election, nomination, or recomendation of them to the people, for their Kings, did not make them Kings, I meane actuall, formall and compleat Kings; no, nor yet his inclining their hearts to a willingnesse to accept of them for their Kings, and to invest them with their power, but their actuall acceptation or receiving of them, for their Kings. Saul was not a King, that is, had no right or authority to exercise any Regall power by vertue of Gods election or nomination of him to the Kingdome, till Samuel had presented him unto all the people, as nominated by God to be their King, and the people gave their consent and approbation of him accordingly, in that acclamation, God save the King, 1 Sam. 10. 24. The people in this their acceptation of him for their King, were the immediate givers of the Kingdome unto him, because this being done, he had a lawfull power to exercise Regall authority over the people immediately, and without the intervening of any further act of God. Nor had David, though nominated and designed long before by God himselfe to the Kingdome; any right to exercise Regall power by vertue of that designation, untill the men of Judah came, and annointed him King in Hebron, 2 Sam. 2. 4. Nor had he any right by vertue of his annointing, to exercise any Regall power over any other of the Tribes, save
onely that Tribe which annointed him, and thereby declared their acceptation of him for their King. Hee was not King over all Israel, till all the Tribes came to him, and by their Elders anointed him King over Israell, therby declaring their consents and approbations to have him their King also. And now David was invested with Regall power and authority. So that the Sun in his might shines not clearer, then this truth, that God was not the immediate but onely the mediate giver of their Kingdoms, both unto Saul and David. And though it had bin sinnefull in the People to have refused either of them for their King, being by Name, and by the ministery of a great Prophet recommended unto them by God yet had such a refusall bin made of them by the people, there is no reason to thinke that they had ever bin Kings. And therefore God himselfe divides betweene himselfe and his people the constitution of a King amongst them, after this manner; that he will have the choice or nomination of him, but they shall have the investiture, or the actuall and immediate making of him a King. When thou art come into the Land which the Lord God giveth thee, and shalt possesse it, and shalt dwell therein, and shalt say; I will set a King over me, like as all the Nations that are about me: thou shalt in any wise set (or make, as the former translation reads it) him King over thee, whom the Lord thy God shall chuse: thou mayst not set a stranger over thee, &c Deut. 17. 14. 15. Therefore God was onely the mediate or remote cause of their King, themselves the immediate: because election or nomination to an office, alwaies preced's, actuall collation of it.

Hence likewise it fully appeares, how left handed the Bishop is in his understanding of Scriptures. To prove that God was the immediate giver of their Kingdomes to the two Kings mentioned, he cites such passages as these. Thus saith the Lord God of Israel (viz. to David) I anointed thee King over Israell, 2 Sam. 12. 7. and that of Solomon. 1 King. 2. 24. Where he acknolwedgeth that the Lord had established him, and set him on the Throne of David his father; and that of Abijah to Jereboam, 1 Kin. 11. 35. I will take the Kingdome out of his sons hand, and will give it unto thee. All which places onely prove, that
all these Kings were beholding to God for their Kingdomes, and that he by his providence, working and inclining the hearts of the people to accept of them from his hand for their Kings, brought them unto their Thrones. Here is neither proofe, nor shew nor colour of proofe, of Gods being the immediate giver of their Kingdomes. When God saith, Ezek. 20. 25. that he gave them (the people) Statutes that were not good, and judgements wherein they should not live: doth it follow from hence, that God was the immediate giver of them? He was no otherwise the giver of them, then by suffering their Idolatrous Kings and false Prophets to make and to teach Idolatrous Statutes and Doctrines amongst them. These were the immediate givers of these Statutes that were not good, Gene. 19. 29. God is said to have destroyed the Cities of the plaine: doth it follow from hence, that God was the immediate destroyer of them and did not use the ministerie or mediation of fire and brimstone to doe it? The Bishop is every whit as weak in his Theologicalls, as in his logicalls, if he knowes not that any event in providence may be attributed unto, or assumed by God, whatsoever and how many-soever the intermediate or immediate productive causes thereof be, because hee rules and orders and disposeth them all towards the production thereof.

The latter difference between them touching the point in hand, is, whether the power and authority of Kings be originally and primarily the ordinance of God. This the Bishop affirmes without any caution, or explication at all. The Anti-Cavalier must distinguish and explaine, or else deny. If the Bishops meaning be, either first, that God is the primary and Supreame disposer of thrones and Kingdomes, and that there is no man invested with regall power and authority, but that he is more indebted unto God, then unto any man, or men whatsoever, for it: or Secondly, if his meaning be, that God is the originall and prime mover of the hearts of a people, to set a King over them whensoever they doe it, being otherwise at liberty to erect what forme of Government amongst themselves they please. or Thirdly, if his meaning be, that God gives men the light of Reason, judgment and understanding,
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
whereby they are able to contrive and shape out such a forme or tenor of Regall power or authority, that the use and administration of it may be commodious and beneficiall unto them, in all these three sences, the Anti Cavalier can shake hands with the Bishop, in his opinion, that the power and authority of Kings is orginally and primarily from God. But if his meaning be (as the whole tenor of his Discourse gives it to be) that God at first, immediately and by himselfe, without the intervention of the reasons and wills of men, drew a particular platforme or modell of Regall government, power, or authority, which he hath imposed upon the World as an Ordinance, for all Nations, or for any Nation, to set up amongst them; in this sence the Anti-Cavalier bids defiance to the Bishops opinion, maintaining the power and authority of Kings to be originally and primarily the Ordinance of God.
His Reasons are these.

Reas: 1 1o. Neither doe the Scriptures, nor any other Author, so much as mention any such draught or plat-forme of Regall Authority, composs'd immediately by God himselfe; much lesse doe they mention any imposition by God of any such plat-forme upon the World to be observed. Therefore it is either pure ignorance or impudence in the Bishop, to father any such opinion: As for his discovery of all the parts of regall power Synechdochically set down, by God. when immediately after the stood he ordained the revenging sword of blood shed and the slavish servitude of paternall derision, (p. 47.) it is a discovery of the same Calculation with his, who lately found a Sea and Land and woods and Rivers, and (upon the matter) another world in the Moone. Certainely it is as lawfull, and as agreeable to this Ordinance of God, that blood-shed should be avenged by the sword of any other forme of government, as in that which is Regall, and by inferiour Magistrates, in case their Authority will extend unto it, as the authority of Judges doe, as by the King himselfe. If the man can acquit himself no better in stating the Episcopall function from the Scriptures, then here he doth the Regall; (and I suspect his insufficiencie paralell in both) he will leave me under a strong jealousie that he is a plant which Christs Heavenly Father never
planted, and consequently must ere long be plucked up.

Reas: 2 2o. If Regall power and authority bee originally the Ordinance of God (in the sence Episcopall) then every forme of Regall power, which swerves or varies from that patterne or platforme, which is the ordinance of God, must needs bee a corruption of an Ordinance of God, and consequently sinfull and unlawfull. The sequel of this Proposition is undeniable. Every ordinance of God hath a certaine, limited and determinat nature, whereby it is distinguished, and may be known from all other things; and the substituting of any other thing in the name or place of an ordinance of God, is a sin, and that of a high nature.
Therefore I assume.
But every forme of Regall power, which swerves or varies from that pattern which is supposed to be the ordinance of God is not sinfull, or unlawfull. Ergo;

For the explication of this latter Proposition, it is to bee considered, that there are scarce any two forms of Regall government in exercise at this day in the world, but differ, and that in matters of such consequence, that if the one bee the Ordinance of God, the other is a corruption of this Ordinance, and so unlawfull. I suppose there is no such Government or power in any Nation, but is somewaies limited and bounded either by lawes, or customes, or covenants, or persons, or the like: and very hard it is, nay (doubtlesse) unpossible to find two Regall Governments in all the world, whose frame and fashion, whose bars and limitations are altogether the same. Whence it must needs follow, that if there bee any such forme of Government, whether Regall or whatsoever, that is an ordinance of God, (in the sense now argued) there can be but one, if there be any at all, lawfull government in the world. For all governments differing from that, which is agreeable to the Ordinance of God are corruptions thereof, and so unlawfull. So then, till the Bishop can find out that Regall government in the world, which is the Ordinance of God, by his divinity all governments by Kings must bee questionable; and when that one is found out. all the rest besides, are evicted therby to be unlawfull. And thus we
see the truth of that saying, Prov. 27. 14. fullfilled in this mans importune standing up to make Kings greater then God hath made them; Hee that blesseth his friend with a loud voice, rising earely in the morning, it shall be counted a curse to him. His opinion of Kingly power and authority, being originally and primarily the ordinance of God, being interpreted is enough to make the Crownes of all the Kings upon earth, to droope and languish, and sit loose upon their heads.

p.hi: It is like, that he will lay hold of this shield and buckler, to save the life of his opinion, if it may be, Kings were originally ordained and appointed by God to rule: and this is sufficient to prove Kingly rule or Government to be originally and primarily the Ordinance of GOD.

div.p:
Answ: 1 To this I Answer, first, It can never bee proved that Kings were originally ordained by God to rule. The first we read of, that assumed Regall power, was Nimrod, Gen, 10. 8. of whom it is said, that he began to bee a mightie one in the Earth; and his Kingdome is spoken of, vers. 10. There is not the least mention made, nor intimation given, that God had any thing to doe with the advancement of him to his Kingdome, by any ordinance or command of his; either to himselfe to rule as a King, or to the people overwhom hee Reigned, to receive him, or subject themselves unto him, as a King. Nor is their any colour to thinke, that either hee should have sin'd against any ordinance of God, in case hee had not made himself a King, or, that the people should have sin'd any such sin, in case they had not received him. It is true, God in a way of a generall and permissive providence, so disposeth of the pride and ambition of Nimrod's heart on the one hand, and of the weakenesse and ignorance of the people one the other, that betweene them both, Nimrod became a King. But had Kingly rule or government bin an ordinance of God, doubtlesse he would never have lay'd the foundation of it in such a Tyrant and oppressor as he was. He should never have hansel'd such a solemn and sacred Ordinance of GOD as this is pretended to be. The next King heard of in the Scriptures, is Pharaoh King of Egypt, Gen. 12. 15. and afterward Chap. 14. we heare of Kings by
heaps, foure making warre against five, and five against foure: but that any of these were put into their Kingdomes by God (otherwise then in a way of permissive and disposive providence, as was said) or by any ordinance of his, is as cleare as the heavens are to us in the darkest night. But

Answ: 2 Secondly, suppose it could be never so substantially prov'd, that men were at first ordayned and appointed by God (in the sence Episcopall) to take Kingly rule upon them, yet except it can be as substantially proved, what the nature, purport, extent, and limits of that rule or power which they exercised by vertue or warrant of that ordinance of God, were, there is nothing gotten by this, to justifie any Regall power now in exercise in the world. Though we could prove never so sufficiently, that Christ or his Apostles ordayned Pastors and Teachers in the Church to preach the Gospell, yet except we both knew what this Gospell was which they were ordayned to preach, and what this preaching it selfe was, the proofe of that Ordination by Christ and his Apostles, would not prove the Pastors and Teachers amongst us ever to have bin ordayned by them. Communion in Name between a present practise, and a practise ordayned by God, is a ridiculous foundation in reason, to prove the present practise to have bin ordayned by God. Therfore the Bishops opinion, that the Kingly Government which is now administrd in the world, is originally the ordinance of God, will starve, notwithstanding this reliefe.

Reas: 3 Thirdly, That Government or power which God never imposed upon any people under heaven to erect or set up amongst them, is not like to be the ordinance of God, command of observation to persons whom it concernes, being an essentiall adjunct of an ordinance of God. But God never imposed the government of Kings upon any Nation, but hath left all Nations free to erect amongst themselves what government they please, whether Aristocraticall, Democraticall, and however mixt, so it be just and lawfull, as well as Regall. Therfore government Regall (in the sence Cathedrall) is not the ordinance of God. The latter Proposition, viz. That God hath left all Nations free to set what
Government themselves please; over them, and consequently hath not imposed upon them that which is Regall, is evident from his owne grounds, who p. 48 affirmeth God to be the allower and confirmer of Aristocraticall and all other forms of Government. From whence I thus reason: If God bee the Allower and confirmer of all other formes of government, as well as of Regall, then were all Nations at liberty to set up any other forme of government, as well as it; for a man is at liberty to doe any thing, which God will allow and confirme when he hath done it: yea it is no whit lesse then blasphemy, to make God the Allower of what is sinfull or unlawfull to be done.

Reas: 4 4o If Government Regall be no otherwise from God, or no otherwise an ordinance of God, then inferiour Magistracy and power is, then is it not originally and primarily from God. Sed verum prius; Ergo et posterius. The sequel in the Proposition is strong, as well, quoadrem as quoad hominem: quoadrem, because inferiour Magistracy, is both confer'd and given, and likewise limited and specified by men, either by the Soveraign power of the King himself as in such Officers and Magistrates, as his lawfull Prerogative gives him right and power to create: or else by the people, as in those Magistrates whose nomination and investiture either by law or priviledge of lawfull custome, belongs unto them: Quoad hominem; because he holds, that all inferiour Magistracy or power, is of a farre inferiour descent and origination, in comparison of that which is Regall. And that it is wholly dependent upon this page 47, 65, 66. The truth of the assumption or antecedent, viz: that government Regall is no otherwise from God, then inferiour Magistracy or government is, is evident.

1o. Because this is said to be from Heaven, and to be ordained of God, as well as that: The Scripture makes no difference or distinction, betweene the descent of the one and of the other, in this respect. Himselfe taketh notice (p. 47.) that Christ doth positively affirme that the power of Pilate was given him from Heaven; Which is indeed expresly so affirmed by him, Joh. 19. 11. excepting only that the Bishop paraphraseth
our Saviours from above, with his, from Heaven: For which though I cannot commend him, yet shall it bee no part of my contention with him at this time. Now Pilate all men know, had no Soveraigne or regall power, but was a subordinate magistrate, deputed to his place of government and rule by the Romane Emperour, and might at pleasure have bin removed by him. So againe, Rom. 13. 1. it is said of all powers (viz. in rule and government) without any distinction, that they are ordained of God: and that there is no power (that is, no lawfull power whatsoever) but is of God: For there is no power but of God, the powers that bee (whether Soveraigne, or subordinate) are ordained of God. Againe,

2o. There is the same subjection, or subjection upon the same terms, charged upon the consciences of men, to the one authority, which is unto the other. Submit your selves to every Ordinance of man for the Lords sake, whether it bee to the King as Supreame, or unto Governors, as unto them that are sent by him, &c. 1 Pet. 2. 13, 14. Therefore there is no ground in Scripture, to conceive any other manner or kind of the issuing or descent of the Regall power from God, then is of the subordinate. All the difference which reason can demonstrate in this kind, is onely this; that the disposall of the hearts of people, and of other circumstances therewith concurring, to bring a King to a Throne, or Soveraignty of rule and power, is ordinarily a farre greater and more considerable act of divine providence; either for the benefit or bane of a people, then the moving of the heart of the King, or the disposing of other interveniences, for the bringing of a man to an inferiour place of Magistracy or power. But this is rather a difference in degree, then in kind

Reas: 5 5o. If Regall government be the ordinance of God, according to the Ossorian glosse and interpretation, then cannot the desire or request of a Nation or people to have this government over them be called a rejecting of God from Raigning or ruling over them. But this desire or request made by the nation of the Jewes is by God himselfe interpreted, a rejecting or casting of him away, that he should not raigne over them, 1 Sam. 8. 67. Therefore certainely the Bishop of OSSORY is
Clericus absque libro, nec valet ova duo; in his notion of Regall government being the ordinance of God. The assumption comes from the mouth of God, almost, and as good as, interminis, let the Bishop deny it at his perill. And for the Proposition, the very sound of it is such and so distinct in the eare of reason, that a reasonable man cannot lightly but prepare his assent unto it immediately. For can any thing lightly be supposed more unreasonable, then that God should challenge and charge a people with a rejection of him, and his rule over them, onely because they desire such a rule or forme of government amongst them, which is an ordinance of his after a more speciall and excellent manner, then any other?

Reason 6 6. That rule of Government, the non-exercise or non-use whereof throughout the whole World, would not have rendred any man sinnefull or displeasing unto God, is not such a divine and supertranscendent ordiance of God above all other formes of Rule and government, as the Ossorian Oracle reports it to be. I remember I have to do with men so unreasanoble, that if such a saying as this that twice two make foure; should make against them they are ready to cry out of the ignorance and impudence of him that should affirme it: otherwise the Proposition laid downe, hath a consistence with reason and truth, manifest enough. But now, to bind the tongue of perversenesse to her good behaviour, take this String or Cord, that it no wayes suites with the glory of the wisdome of God; to set his seale of speciall excellencie upon any ordinance of his and then to leave all the World at liberty, whether they will use it, or obey it or no. Therefore let mee now assume.

But the non-exercise, or non-use of Kingly government, had the world generally ag ••• d never to have used or imbra
•••
〈…〉 not 〈…〉 the World, nor any member 〈…〉 God Ergo.

T ••
〈…〉
•••• ent from what hath bin already argued 〈…〉 no Nation but might lawfully have 〈…〉 government, as well as this (which 〈…〉 ) evident it is, tha • their refusing of this government had bin no wayes sinnefull. If the Observation
or use of the Regall government had bin necessary in point of duty, or had the government it self bin such a choice and divine Ordinance above all other governments, doubtlesse God would have imposed it upon his owne people, the Nation of the Jewes, though he had left others to their liberty. But that he no wayes so much as recommended it unto them, but left them purely to themselves, whether they would set up a King over them or no; is every whit as much as fully evident, Deut. 17. 14. When thou art come to the Land which the Lord thy God giveth thee, and shalt possesse it and shalt dwell therein, and shalt say I will set a King over me like as all the Nations that are about me, thou shalt in any wise set him King over thee, whom the Lord thy God shall chuse, &c. God doth not here say, that when they came into their Land, he would set a King over them or have them to set a King over them; but onely that in case they should say that they would set up a King over them; that is should freely and voluntarily desire or resolve upon such a government, that then for the person of him that should bee their King, he would have the election or nomination of him.

Wee know that God himselfe had setled them under an other government, viz: by Judges, wherein he had blessed and prospered them many yeers: and though it was not simply unlawfull for them to desire a King to beset over them (as appeares from the place in Deuteronomie last cited) yet this desire of theirs proceeding out of a dislike or discontentment at that government which God himselfe had set over them, or out of a superstitious conceipt of some divine excellency or perfection in the government they desired, above that which already they injoyed, was on high breach betweene him and them.

If it bee lawfull to speake the truth withall simplicity and ingenuitie, I professe I never yet met with any sollid, or convincing argument, either from Scripture or otherwise, to prove that Regall government or power is in any other sense or consideration the ordinance of God, then in those three formerly expressed.

As for those Scriptures, by me Kings Reigne, &c. Prov. 8. 15. and again, There is no power, but of God: the powers that bee, are ordained
of God, Rom. 13. 1. with others of like consideration, they determine nothing in way of any speciall modification, as how, or in what sense whether originally and primarily, or secondarily, or demonstratively, onely whether mediately or immedily, either Kingly power, or any other be ordained by GOD: much lesse doe they conclude any thing by way of Prerogative for the manner of the issuing of Kingly power from God above any other All that they prove is that Kingly government and power, as well as any other, are simply from God, and are ordained, or rather ordered ( 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) by God; which is a conclusion, wherewith the Anti-Cavalier is ready to fill the Bishops bosome with both his hands. As for those Episcopall modifications and explications of this conclusion which have bin argued, we have seen nothing liker the chaffe before the wind, then they.

div.head: CAP. III. Wherein the Bishops second encounter against the Anti-Cavalier, about the carriage of the Prophet Elisha, towards him that was sent to take away his head, 2 King. 6. 32 Is examined.
div.p:
VVHen Herod had killed James the brother of John with the sword, the text saith, that because he saw that it pleased the people, he proceeded further to take Peter also, Act. 12. 2, 3. The Bishop (it seems) hath either so pleased himself or his friends, with confuting the Anti-Cavalier (over the shoulder) once, that he proceeds to a like confutation of him the second time. The Anti-Cavalier pleads the practise and example of the Prophet Elisha, who caused the doore to be shut, and the Cavalier, that was sent to take away his head, to be roughly handled, for lawfullnesse of resistance, against unlawfull executioners of unlawfull commands. That quarter in this discourse,
which the Philo-Cavalier falls upon, is this: surely hee that went thus farre (viz: as to cause the doore to bee shut, and the messenger of blood to bee roughly handled without) for the safety of his life, when he was but in danger of being assaulted, would have gone further if occasion had bin: and in case the Kings Butcher had got into him, before the doore had bin shut, if he had bin able, and had had no other meanes to have saved his owne head, but by taking away the others; there is little question to be made, but he would rather have taken, then given an head, in this case.

Against this, the Bishop advanceth with this answer (such as it is) that who this GOODWIN is, he knowes not: but he could wish, he were none of the Tribe of Levi, 2o. Because he finds him such an incendiary of Warre, &c. 2o because his objection is full of falsehoods, and false grounds, &c.

If a man could answer objections, either with ignorance, or with a wish, I see there is no man like to a Bishop to cope with an adversary. For the forlorne hope or first advance of his answer, is, that hee knowes not who this Goodwin is, that set's the Prophet Elisha thus upon his back to vexe him. But doth not the man deny himself deeply, thus ingenuously to confesse his ignorance? No doubtlesse; it is very rare to find a Bishop under this Fig-tree. The designe of this confession rather seemes to bee to indigitate his adversary as a filius terrae, and contemptible and obscure person, and himself brother to the Sun and Moone, a man of renowne. However, the lamb had no great cause to be sorry if the wolfe knew her not. Nor hath this Goodwin any cause to bee troubled, that these great overseers overlooke him: he hath bin known to some of them to his cost. But though this son of the morning knowes not this Goodwin (that Ignorant and impudent fellow he spake of before) yet he knows Master Griffith to be a learned Divine, p. 94. and Mr Warmstry to be a learned preacher of Gods word, pag 32. both of them (I believe) men as much unknowne to him, as this Goodwin, excepting onely the relation of co-Malignancy or con-temporizing between them.

2o. In the next place comes on the Vanne of his Answer, which is a wish, yet of no great strength neither, but a kind
of velleitie: hee could wish that this GOODWIN were none of the Tribe of Levi. It is no strange thing for a Bishop to wish evill unto men: they have both the will and the deed, (in this kind) given unto them. I believe he could wish not onely that this GOODWIN, but that all the Ministers within the three Kingdomes, that are faithfull and through-hearted in the worke of the Gospel, were none of the Tribe of Levi; nor (I feare) of any other Tribe, but of that which is not.
But it may bee the crookednesse of his wish, may bee made straight by the reasons and grounds of it. Let these therfore stand forth, and plead for their master.

The first is, because he finds him such an incendiary of warre, and enemy unto peace. Such an incendtary? such an enemie? I pray as who? as your selfe, and men of your Order? Or as St. Paul and the rest of his Order? If he be such an incendiary of war, or enemy to peace as you and yours, let him smart for it: he deserves it. I shall never open my mouth, nor stirre my pen for him. For you annimate and exhort, and egge on all that have no more conscience then to hearken to you, to strengthen the hand of those that are risen up against that Honourable Assembly, the supreme Judicatorie or Court of Justice in the Land, and in them against the peace and safety of all his Majesties 3 Kingdomes; you (I say) stirre up all you can with both your hands to asiist and strengthen these men in their way, to the utmost of their power, by not sparing their goods, nor being niggards in their contributions: nay, you blow these coales yet hotter, and thrust them forward in this desperate service, even to the hazard and losse both of libertie and life, (pag. 105, 106. of your Discourse.) It is true, you baite your hook with the glossie pretence of His Majesties safety and protection, as if you call'd in all this helpe and assistance only for these: but your reall intentions are so notorious, and so strong above ground, that you gaine nothing by all your flourishes and pretences in this kind, but the deserved reproach of base hypocrasie and dissimulation on the one hand, and of being the generation of him that is called the accuser of the Brethren, one the other. For by your importune
crying out for ayd and assistance to be brought in, for the safety and protection of his Majesty, you plainly insinuate, that it is the Parliament and those faithfull and loyall Subjects of his that stand by them for their defence and safety, that indanger his Majesty, and seek his life, Crown, and dignities: which is an accusation and charge of that desperate falshood and malice, that the Accuser of the Brethren we speake of, seemes to have given you his power and his Throne, as being more able to manage them for his advantage, then himselfe. This is to be an incendiary of warre, and an enemy to peace, to seek to disturbe, and to oppose the proceedings of Law and Justice throughout the Land, to endeavour to strengthen the hand of malefactors and delinquents, that they may be able to wage warre against their lawfull and righteous Judges, to incence the people against those Rulers and Magistrates of theirs, who with upright hearts and unwearied endeavours, seeke the things of their peace and welfare, against those that have already more then begun to devoure them and are upon terms of advantage enough to finish their worke, and to make an utter end of them, if the people themselves will be perswaded to joyne with them, and to help them, as you would have them.

In this sence therfore, evident it is, that the Philo-Cavalier, not the Anti-Cavalier, is the Incendiary of warre, and enemie to peace. But in what sence, I pray will the accusation hold against the Anti-Cavalier? How is he an incendiary of warre? He exhorts and perswades people all he can, to keep their late vow and Protestation made unto God (not disallowed that ever I heard by his Majesty himselfe) as viz. to maintaine and defend, as farre as lawfully they may, with their lives, power, and estates, the true Reformed Protestant Religion; his Majesties Royall person, honour 〈◊〉 estate the power and Priviledges of Parliament; the lawfull Rights and Liberties of the Subject, and every person that should make the same protestation in whatsoever he should doe in the lawfull persuance of the same.
