And • o their power, and as farre as lawfully they may, to oppose, and 〈◊〉 good wayes and meanes endeavour to bring to condig •• punishment, all such as shall either by force, practise, counsells, plots, conspiracie or otherwise, doe any thing to the
contrarie of any thing in the said protestation contained: And neither for feare, hope, nor other respect, to relinquish this promise, vow and protestation. If the Anti-Cavalier hath moved little or much out of this his sphere let the Bishop beare testimony against him and upon due proof made, Satiet se sanguine, quem semper sitivit: let the Anti-Cavalier be sacrificed upon the service of his Anti-Christian and bloody spirit as an incendiarie of warre, and enemy to peace: but in the mean time (which I make no question will be long enough) let the saddle be set upon the right Horse, and he that cryes out against the thiefe, be laid hold of for the thief himselfe.
The second reason why he wishes this Goodwin out of his Tribe of Levi, is, because his objections is full of falshoods and false grounds.

But good Sir, this is an hard case, to wish a man unpriested, because he makes an objection, with falsehoods and false grounds in it. If you ever have beene at the Universitie, or know any thing of the disputations there, you cannot but know, that Objections generally are falsholds, and built upon false grounds; yea and that, in case the respondent undertakes to defend the truth (which is presumed he alwayes doth; at least as farre as his judgement leadeth him) unpossible it is that any disputation should be maintained, but onely by Obiections and Arguments that are falshoods, it being unpossible to oppose truth with truth. But I can easily excuse the man, though hee hath forgotten the use and signification of his termes in Logique, calling that an objection which is an Argument: These were but the Nuts of his Boy-hood and youth. A great States-man, that hath his part and share of the burthen of two or three great Kingdoms upon his shoulder, and all these in a grievous combustion, uprore, and confusion; is he at all to be blam'd, if he neglects the punctill'os and formalities of his Logique and hath no leisure to aske his wits the question, how Sophisters speake in the Schooles.

In the head of his charge, he learnedly distinguisheth between falshoods and false ground; but in making good his charge by insisting upon particulars, he confounds them again, as he doth himselfe. Well, but what are the falshoods or false grounds
(call them what you will) wherewith the Anti-Cavaliers objection, or argument (call it what you will, Bishops are for liberty) is so full?
Now to the heat and strength of the battell. His first charge is, that the Anti-Cavalier saith in his Objection, that Ahab sent to take Elisha's head, whereas Ahab was dead long before.

I answer, 1o. that the Bishop (it seemes) hath lighted upon a mis-printed Copy, wherein he met with the Father instead of the Sonne. A man would think that it were his hard hap, to light upon Bibles much mis-printed also, his opinions in divinity, being so dissenting from all Hagiographie of a true impression.

But 2o. Whereas he saith, that Ahab was dead long before; I demand of him, as hee doth of the Anti-Cavalier a few lines after (in another case) what inspiration hee hath from God to bee sure of this? The Scripture determineth nothing of the interim, betweene Ahabs death, and this fact of his Sonne Iehoram.

But he goeth on and courteously granteth, that the Prophet, in his judgement, desiring the Elders to handle the messenger roughly; or hold him fast at the doore, did herein a little more, then what God and nature alloweth every man to doe, not to lay down his life, if he can lawfully preserve it, &c.

Where is to be noted, that though hee doth not cry out against the Prophet Elisha for shutting the doore, as hee doth against the Anti-Cavalier, nor against Christ, for giving leave, when we are persecuted in one City, to fly into another, yet in his judgment the doing of the one and of the other, was A LITTLE MORE then what God and nature allowed every man to do? It is no marveile if hee makes himself so much wiser then his poore Brethren whom he look's upon as so many Ignaro's, and insults over their ignorance with his knowledge, when as Prophets themselves, yea and the Lord of Prophets himselfe being weighed in his ballance, have much adoe to (nay do not fully) hold out with his weights.

But in all this which the Prophet did, hee tells us, that hee finds no violent resistance, What? and yet somewhat more then
what God and nature, alloweth every man to doe? Well, but yet he is here somewhat ingenuous and tender: he doth not absolutely deny, but that here might be some violent resistance; only he professeth that he finds none. Juglers can hide and find at pleasure. The man (I believe) hath learned his Terence: Si sapis, quod scis, nescis: and his Cato too, who teacheth him that principle of policy, which here he makes use of.
div.q:
Stultitiam simulare loco prudentia summa est,
i. e.
'Tis wisedom's highest strain, as time and place may be.
Wiselesse to make thy self, and nothing for to see.
div.p: If His Majestie should come to demand entrance into any of the walled Cities of this Kingdome and those within should shut the gates against him, and not suffer him to enter, and withall should handle him roughly at the Gates: I believe the mans eyes would now bee opened, and hee would find violent resistance here. If by violent resistance he means, laying on dry blowes with a weapon, or cleaving a mans head in sunder with a Skaine or battell-Axe: I confesse that neither doe I (in this sense) find any violent resistance. But if by violent resistance, he meanes a strong and forcible opposition, a withstanding an assailant to the utmost of a mans power, at least to the uttermost of what was necessary to prevent the mischief that was intended against him, doubtlesse a violent resistance is easie enough to bee found in the Prophets carriage in this place. Nor did the Anti-Cavalier ever intend a legitimation of any further resistance by way of violence or force, then onely to such a degree, which may in prudence be thought fully sufficient to stave off the violence and iniustice of those, who without any lawfull authority shall advance against them. His meaning never was, to make it lawfull to draw a sword, when the shutting of a doore may be a sufficient security.

But the words of the Bishops greatest indignation, against the Anti-Cavalier in this passage, are these: Surely if the messenger had got in, Elisha had taken of his head, rather then given his owne. Here he demands, what inspiration the Anti-Cavalier
hath from God to be sure of this? Withall affirming, that hee was sure that John Baptist would not doe so, nor St. Paul, nor any other of Gods Saints that he had read of: but these men are sure of every thing, even of Gods secret counsell, and that is more then the thoughts of mens hearts, &c.

I answer, 1o. I shall pardon the Bishops mangling and curtailing the Anti-Cavaliers words for his owne advantage in this place, because hee had done honestly in a iust report of them before, whither the Reader may please to repaire for a full view of them. But

2o. Whereas he demands, by what inspiration from God, his Antagonist was sure of this? I answer, by a farre better inspiration, then the Bishop had, either to affirme, that the Christians that were at Ierusalem when James was martyred, were more in number, and greater in power, then were the persecutors of that Apostle, which yet hee makes no bones to avouch, p. 21. or to say, p. 56. that neither Joseph in swearing by the life of Pharoah, nor the midwives in lying to the King, sinned: or then hee had to say, p. 68. that whatsoever the King hath suffered, all the world knowes it is for the preservation of the Protestant Religion, of the established lawes of this Kingdome, &c. I marvaile, first; by what inspiration all the world should know it. And I marveile yet more, by what inspiration the Bishop should know that all the World knowes it. And I would gladly know by what inspiration from God, he Prophesies and forsees, p. 68. that those Reverend Bishops, grave Doctors, and all the rest of the Learned and Religious Clergie, for whose preservation (as hee; like himselfe fableth) the King suffers, will to the spilling of the last drop of their blood, defend the truth (I thinke he meanes of Protestant Religion, or that the King suffers all for the preservation of this Religion, &c.) Against all Papists, and other Anabaptisticall Brownists and Sectaries whatsoever. Surely to determine and prophesie what himselfe would doe in such a case as hee here speakes of, requires no lesse then the knowledge of Gods secret Counsell. For 1o. the man by his owne strength, and without speciall assistance from God, is not able to defend any truth of God, to the spilling of the first, much lesse to the spilling of the last drop of his blood; as wee see in the example of
Peter, another manner of man to defend the truth with his blood, then the Bishop is (no dispraise to him) And 2o. Whether God will assist any man, much more a colloguing Bishop, so farre, when it comes to the tryall, as to defend a truth to the last drop of his blood, is not revealed, and therfore must needs be the secret counsell of God. But to undertake, that others; I know not how many more, even all the learned and Religious Clergie, shall doe it, requires a greater inspiration in the kind, then ever Prophet Apostle, or Evangelist had. Yet let me advise a little better upon the Bishops expression, in that word, Religious: It may bee I may have cause to correct my selfe (in part) in what I have said. If his meaning be that all the Religious Bishops, Doctors and Clergie, for whose preservation his Majestie so suffers, will to the spilling of the last drop of their blood, defend the truth of Religion: I confesse this may be very reasonably (as touching the truth of it) and in a way of good probability affirmed, without any extraordinary inspiration from God. For this is but a saying of like notion with this; that all the Fishes in the Sea, that are foules in the aire, are able to fly: or this, all the Lambs in the Fold, that are Lyons in the Forrest, will bee able enough to deale with the Wolfe, when hee comes. Both these are truths manifest enough, though but simple ones.

In such a figure and Character of speech as this, all the Bishops, Doctors, and Clergie (for whose preservation the King suffers) that are Religious, may well defend the truth of Religion, to the spilling of the last drop of their blood.

But to give the Bishop an accompt, by what inspiration from God, the Anti Cavalier affirmeth, that the prophet in case he had had no other meanes to escape, and had bin able, would rather have taken, then given, an head: he might very well, upon consideration of what the Prophet had done, speake this by the inspiration of reason, and (almost) of common-sence. For it is very reasonable to thinke and say, that hee that goes one mile to save his life, will goe two, if hee bee able; and there be no other meanes wherby to save it, The Prophet (doubtlesse) did more, more I meane in a geometricall or rationall proportion, in causing the Butcher to bee roughly handled,
and the doore to be shut against him, whilst hee was yet at such a distance from doing him harme, then hee should have done in taking away his head, in case he had got within him, and could by no other meanes have saved his owne. That confidence he pretends that neither John the Baptist, nor Paul would doe so, supposing all circumstances should have paralell'd (for otherwise he speakes to little purpose) is but the inspiration of his Chaire, neither doth he so much as plead or pretend, any better ground for it.

But the Bishop himselfe (it seemes) makes no great treasure of this answer of his neither, but (in effect) grants, that it is very likely that the Prophet would have served the Cavalier neither better nor worse, then as the Anti-Cavalier conceiveth he would have done, had matters come to that exigent he proposeth; and therefore (in the third and last place) hee casts out his sacred Anchor, betakes himselfe to his bottome answer, the best of all the strength he had to oppose, which is this; That Elisha was a great Prophet, and had the spirit of Elijah doubled upon him; and those actions that he did, or might have done, through the inspiration of Gods spirit; this man may not doe, except he be sure of the like inspiration.

I Answer, Elishas being a great Prophet, and having the spirit of Elijah doubled upon him, hindreth not at all, but that the Anti-Cavalier, yea and the Philo-Cavalier too, may doe, yea and ought to doe, hic et nunc, consenting, many things which hee did, and might have done by the inspiration of Gods Spirit; yea many things, without asking the consent of hic et nunc themselves. I presume Elisha prayed unto God, loved God and men, by the inspiration of Gods spirit: and will not the Bishop allow either himselfe or others, to doe these things, as well as hee? I confesse Bishops have bin very chary and tender in granting this liberty; and where it hath bin taken over-deepe, the High Commission hath made transgression and money of it.

Yea but the Bishop meanes the extraordinary inspiration of the Spirit of God; and supposeth that the Prophet did what hee did in the premisses, by such an inspiration; and hereupon concludes his example to be no pattern or warrant for imitation.

I Answer, if this be the meaning. then have at the Butcher with his owne Hatchet; why doth he (a few lines before as we heard) say, that the Prophet in his judgment did, in what he did, but little more then what God and nature alloweth every man to doe? And why doth he say a few lines after, that indeed the place is plaine, that Elisha made no other resistance, but what every man may lawfully doe, &c. Surely he that saith these things doth not thinke that Elisha did what he did, in the particulars so much insisted upon, by extraordinary inspiration of the spirit of God. The truth is, that there are no fewer then three notorious inconsistencies or contradictions, within the compasse of this his answer. First, his judgement is, that the Prophet did a little more (though but a little more) then what God and nature alloweth every man to doe, Secondly, his judgement (contrary to that) is, that the place is plain, that he made no other resistance, but what every man may lawfully doe. Thirdly, his judgement (contrary to both) is, that what Elisha did in this case, he did it by the extraordinary inspiration of the Spirit of God. He that thus turnes himselfe every way, and cuts and slasheth himselfe (like Baals Priests) for an answer, is it not a plaine signe that he knowes not which way to turne him for an answer to purpose? The common saying is, Nusquam est, qui ubique est. And yet notwithstanding as if he had quitted himself like a man and laid his adversary flat, hee comes downe from the theatre with this triumphant song in his mouth; yet this man would inferre hence, that we may lawfully, with a strong hand, and open warre, resist the authority of our lawfull King. The truth is, that for any thing the other man hath answered or said, this man or any other man, may inferre from the premisses what they will. But he that gives power and authority to a King, to doe what he pleaseth, p. 29. here takes the like power and authority to himselfe to speake what he pleaseth. A Reverend Bishop would bee ashamed to lay his mis-begotten Childe at an honest mans doore. Verily you deserve to sit no more in Parliament, till you can shew, where the Anti-Cavalier hath made such an inference as you charge him with, viz: that we may lawfully, with a strong hand and open warre; resist the authority of a lawfull King, and if you be kept out till then, your
returne will be ad Calendas Grecas, the very punctuall precise time desired by all true lovers of the Gospell, for your re-advancement thither. The Anti Cavalier never thought it never spake it, never delivered it by pen or otherwise, that it was lawfull for us or any man to resist the authority of a lawfull King. Therefore the Bishop goes out in a snuffe here.

Yet afterwards, p. 62. he would faine have somthing to say, but that he knowes not well what, to those same almost two leaves, which the Anti-cavalier, spends in six severall answers, that hee makes to an objection against the examining of the equitie or iniquity of the Kings commands. Against these almost two leaves he gives sentence pro tribunali, that they are spent to no purpose. If I thought so, my advice should be to have them bound with the Bishop of Ossoryes Grand Rebellion: for better one booke troubled, then two.

But is he as strong in his evidence as he is in his judgment? Not by as many degrees as the Sun went back in the Diall of Ahaz, in Hezekiahs dayes. Make the computation and see. The indictment you have heard already, it is for the crime of impertinency; the evidence is, because we never deny, but that in some cases, though not in all (for there must bee Arcana Imperij, and there must be privy Counsellors; and every Peasant must not examine all the Edicts of his Prince) the commands of Kings may not onely be examined, but also disobeyed, &c.

By the connexion of this reason with the accusation, which it is brought to prove, it seemes the Bishops opinion is, that nothing is written to any purpose, but what is written in opposition to him, and men of his order. For the reason which he gives, why the almost two leaves are written or spent to no purpose, is fairely this, because he and his Copes-mates doe not deny what is there proved. And for this opinion of his, I can very freely goe thus farre along with it, as to thinke, that as the condition and times of the Gospell are for the present, there can nothing lightly be written to better purpose, then what is and may be written in opposition to him and his Hierarchicall com-rades. But if his opinion be (as his reason gives it) that nothing is written to any purpose at all, except it puls some or other of his opinions by the throat, I professe ingenuously
that I have not so bad an opinion of the man, as to set the foot of my judgement by his, in this. I believe hee holds many Orthodox and savoury truths, which may bee handled and pleaded for to very good purpose.

Nor Secondly, doe I apprehend that reason of his to bee of sufficient strength, which he gives why we should make such a distinction or difference betweene a Kings commands as this, that some should be 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , others 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is, some liable to examination; others priviledged and exempt. This reason is, (as hath bin said) because there must be Arcana Imperij, and Privy Counsellors: why, may not a man eat Oysters, without disturbing the Bishop at his rost Beefe? I would fain know, how any examination of any of the Kings commands whatsoever, as farre as concernes the lawfullnes of them in point of execution (and other examination was never dream't of by the Anti-Cavalier) should any wayes prejudice or trench upon Arcana Imperij, or secrets of State, Kings & States may have their secrets, without any impairment either of their number or secrecy, and yet command nothing to be done or put in execution, but what may safely be so farre considered, and thought of, by those to whom the execution is injoyned: as whether they be lawfull to be done by them, or no: The intention of the King or State, in what they command, is not necessary to bee knowne or inquired into, by those that are commanded (especially when either in the judgment of reason or charity, it may be presumed to be good) because it is onely the nature and substance of the act injoyned, that concernes the inferiour, or servant that is to performe it; But these he ought still so farre to examine and inquire into till hee discovers either lawfullnesse or unlawfullnesse in them, and accordingly, either to obey, or to refuse the command. And if there were any such secrets of Kings and States, which required subjection unto their edicts and commands; upon any such termes, that those that are to obey, must not so much as consider, whether it be lawfull for them to obey or no; and to resolve either of obeying or not obeying accordingly; better were it a thousand times that all such secrets should bee prophaned and cashiered, then
maintained or regarded by either. Never let Kings or States thinke to prosper or thrive in greatnesse, by the Revenues or incomes of such Arcana, which cannot be managed but with sin and disobedince unto God.

Thus still we see, that Episcopall batteries and assaults are of no value to pierce or shake the fortifications and bulwarks which the Anti-Cavalier hath raised for the defence of the cause undertaken by him.

div.head: CAP. IV. Wherein the third assault made upon the Anti-Cavalier by the Cavaliering Bishop, is examined, and the Anti-Cavalier faire ly acquitted, either from throwing dirt in the Fathers faces, or dishonouring that noble Army of martyrs, which our Church confesseth, &c.
div.p: THe Philo-Cavalier, in the beginning of his tenth Chap. p. 78. having risen early to commend himself and make a vaunt of what further learning he had yet in banke, for the maintenance of his cause, if need were, hee presently easeth his foule stomacke, by disgorging this vomit in the Anti-Cavaliers face.

But the Anti-Cavalier, would perswade the World that all those learned Fathers, and those constant Martyrs, that spent their purest blood to preserve the purity of Religion unto us, did either belie their owne strength or befoole themselves with the undue desire of over valued Martyrdome. But now they are instructed by a better spirit, they have cleerer illuminations to inform them to resist (if they have strēgth) the best and most lawfull authority, that shall either oppose, or not consent unto them. Thus they throw dirt in the Fathers face and dishonour that glorious companie; and noble Armie of Martyrs, &c.

I see men may rub their foreheads to what degree of hardnesse they please; and by applying stupefactives to their consciences, make them sleepe to what depth of insensiblenesse they desire. Bishops surely are more afraid of scruples and qualms of conscience, then they are of Hell fire they provide so substantially against the one, by exposing themselves without feare or regard unto the other. A man would have thought, that what the Anti-Cavalier hath written touching the Fathers and Martyrs in the premises, being extant; and for every man that desires to looke upon, should have bin a bridle in the lips of th • s mans pen, to have kept • t from breaking out in such notorious slanders and untruths. But, pacta ••• a est: he hath adventured upon a Bishopricke, and 'tis now too late to thinke of uprightnesse. The best ground he could have to utter himselfe as he hath done here, was a hope, that they that loved the spirit of his discourse, and would read with gladnesse what hee hath written, would never vouchsafe to bestow time or paines in reading or considering what the Anti-Cavalier hath said. And the truth is, that there needs none other Answer or confutation to those lines of slander lately recited, but onely the laying of those passages in the Anti-Cavalier by them, whereunto they relate.

For 1o. Where doth the Anti-Cavalier go about to perswade the World, that all the learned Fathers and constant Martyrs, did either bely their owne strength, or befoole themselves with an undue desire of over valued Martyrdome? The charge is so groundlesse, and the spirit of it so irrelative to any thing that the Anti-Cavalier hath written that it is hard to conceive, what passage it is, that should give the occasion of it. The Bishop indeed cites in his Margent, Anti-Cavalier: p. 17. 18. &c. But in all this wood I can find none of the Serpents he speakes of. It is true the Anti-Cavalier laies it down p. 17, 18. as matter of probality, that in case the Christians under the heathen Emperors had bin able enough to have defended themselves, and to have opposed the Emperour and his Party; yet that all christians scattered up and downe the Empire, might not have this apprehension of their strength, or thinke themselves strong enough to resist their Adversaries.
And some lines after; that it was no wayes necessary that they should be all of the same mind and judgement, touching the sufficiency of their strength; and that upon: his ground it might bee, that nothing was attempted in way of resistance by them. This is the utmost line and pin of all that the Anti-Cavalier saith in the pages cited by the Bishop, or elsewhere, touching this particular. Now I would know of a man that had not made shipwrack of his forehead, whether there bee in all this, so much as an appearance of any such designe, as to perswade the World, that all the fathers and Martyrs did belie their owne strength? When as it is expresly granted and supposed, that a great part of the Christians then living, might have an apprehension of the sufficiency of their strength for resistance? Besides, that any one either of the fathers or of the Martyrs, should doubt or question their strength in this kind, is not so much as whispered or intimated in the lowest manner, in all that discourse. Therefore to charge the Anti-Cavalier, that hee should goe about to perswade the World, that all the Fathers and Martyrs should belie their owne strength; when he imputeth no such thing to any one of them, is a slander worthy that order of men from whence it comes, whose tongues and pens notwithstanding (in the sence of our English Proverbe) are no slander.

2o. That he should desire to perswade the World, that all the fore-named Fathers and Martyrs should befoole themselves with the undue desire of overvalued Martyrdome, is as farre from all unreasonable construction that can be made of any thing affirmed by him, as the former charge was. The Anti-Cavalier supposeth it indeed (page 20, 21. of his Discourse) as a thing possible that God might conceale a particular truth in this kind, from the guides and teachers of his Church in those times, and gives such reasons for this his supposition, as the Philo Cavalier (I beleeve cannot take away. 2o. Hee further supposeth, that that spirit of courage, patience and constancy, which God powred out abundantly upon his Church and servants in those times, whereby they were so strengthened and incouraged to suffer that Martyrdome, seem'd a desirable thing unto them, might be an occasion to take them off from inquiring into their lawfull libertie of declining it. And of
this supposition also he gives such an accompt, as the Bishop hath no mind to examine 3o. He supposeth; that whilst there lay a confessed necessitie of suffering upon Christians, 1. till the supposed strength of resistance came to them (which could not bee much lesse then. 200 yeers) Martyrdome was so extolled and magnified by generall acclamations, continuall Panegericks and orations made in the praise thereof, that probable it was, that no man for a long time would have bin • n • ured, that should have taught any doctrine that might any waies seeme to take men off from the desire thereof. This supposition I suppose the Bishop himself will not oppose. 4o. (and lasty) he supposeth that the frame and tenor of Gods after dispersations (viz: as touching Anti-Christs advancement into his Throne) did require, that such a libertie as hee had spoken of, should be hid from his Church or at least that they should not make use of it, In case they had seen it, and had had opportunity, in respect of outward strength to have used it: as on the contrary the nature and purport of those dispensations, which God hath now in hard requires that this liberty should be manifested and made known unto Christians. This Supposition hee further explaineth and proveth, p. 21, 22. of that Discourse. Now set malignity her selfe doe her worst, and breake all the rules of charity seven times over (if she please) only let her observe and keep to rules of Grammar; and let her say what there is in all these passages or suppositions, that carrieth any shew or colour in it to prove that the Anti-Cavalier goes about to perswade the World that all the Fathers and Martyrs befoold themselves with an undue desire of overvalued Martyrdome: or that he throws dirt in the face either of the one, or of the other. He doth not in all these particulars, so much as once positively affirme, that either the one or the other of them were either ignorant of that liberty he speakes of or over-valued Martyrdome; onely he supposeth a possibilty of both.

But suppose he had affirmed both positively, doth it follow, bat therefore he represents all the Fathers and Martyrs, as men that had befoold themselves? Indeed by the Logicke of him that is the inference-maker quidlibet, will follow ex quelibet. His best Logicke (it seemes) consists in a Court of facculties kept in his owne breast out of which hee can dispence
with spurious and illegitimate consequences when hee pleaseth, and give them a capacity of being thought Rationall and cleere.

Doth every man, or any man, that hath not attained the knowledge of some particular conclusion or truth in Religion, therfore befoole himselfe? I presume the Bishop is nescient (not to rub him with the course towell of Ignorance where with notwithstanding hee bescrubs the poor Anti-Cavalier over and over) but nescient I say (doubtlesse) hee is, of many truths lying within the compasse of Divinity, and the Scriptures: will he therfore kindly accept of such a salutation as this from any man: Sir you befoole your self in I know not how many things? Or though his patience and humility be so profound as to take such an Ave kindly himselfe yet is it no wayes consistent with either, for him to speake to others in so course a Dialect.

It is no disparagement to any man that is yet within the verge of mortality to have the circle of his knowledg thought narrower and lesse, the vast circumference of things to bee known. Nor is it any blot upon the Name or memory of him that was sometimes mortall to say of him, that he knew not all things. Because this being interpreted, is no more then to say that he was mortall.

But the Bishop being a Father himselfe, and thirsting as it seemes) after the title of being thought a man omniscient, cannot indure to heare, that those that are known by the Name of Fathers, should be suspected to have bin ignorant of any thing.
But because in this encounter he quits his intellectuals and falls on with his patheticals onely rayling and not reasoning at all: I will be at no farther expence of words upon him, for the present.

div.head: CHAP. V. Wherein the Bishops fourth incounter with the Anti-Cavalier, in which he chargeth him with lies and slanders cast upon the King to make him odious to his Subjects, is examined.
div.p: THE Oyle in his Cruze being formerly spent, the Bishop here comes to his vinegar Bottle. Having run himself out of his small stock of learning before he was aware, with such lavish expence thereof as he made in opposing the Anti-Cavalier by way of argument and reason, in his two first encounters; hee is enforced to mannage his 3. latter with an inferiour element, and to furnish his pen with the rankest slanders and lies he could rake off from the Divells dunghill.
For let himself say, whether he hath not irregularied both himself and his pen with these un-priestly lines, p. 95. of his Grand Rebellion?

But as Absalon knew well enough, that to traduce his Fathers Government, was the readiest way to infinuate, and to wind himselfe into a good opinion with the people, and to make the King odious unto his Subjects: so these and all other Rebels will be sure to lay load enough of lies and slanders upon their governours, and so the namelesse Author of the Soveraigne Antidote, GOOWDIN, Burroughes, and abundance more, such scandalous, impudent, lying Libells, have not blushed (which a man would thinke the brazen face of Sathan could not chuse but doe) so maliciously and reproachfully, to lay to his Majesties charge the things which he never knew, and which all they that know the King, doe know to be apparant lies, and most abominable slanders against the Lords Vicegerent, &c.

The Bishop (it seems) is very ingenuous and charitable towards Sathan; Hee thinkes that his brazen face cannot chuse but blush, so maliciously and reproachfully to lay to His Majesties charge
the things which he never knew, as Goodwin, Burrowghs, and abundance more have done. It is somwhat strange, how the man should come so much as to make conjecture, what Sathans brazen face should doe had he not borrowed it of him, and made an experiment of it himselfe in this kind. Except (haply) he hath gotten a face more brazen then his? which indeed must needs be, if there be that ingenuity in Sathans face, which this charity tempteth him to believe.

For not to blush so maliciously and reproachfully, to lay on such loads, not of apparent but of APPARANT LIES and most abominable slanders, upon Goodwin, and Burrowghs, as here he hath done; requires more brasse in the forehead, I meane a farre higher straine of impudency, then not to blush at any thing which either Goodwin, or Burrowghs, hath charged the King withall. For these men are so farre from laying loads of lies and slaunders upon the King, in what they have written, especially the former, (and I conceive the latter every whit as capable of the same purgation) that they have endeavoured upon all occasions, as farre as a good conscience would consent, to ease such passages, with the fairest interpretation they could put upon them, as in the generall opinion of those amongst whom they live, reflected with some disadvantage upon His Majestie. And therefore not to blush, to charge such men with abominable lies and slanders against his Majesty, requires a face more brazen, then that which himselfe ascribes unto Sathan.

I cannot bethinke my selfe, what piece of Wood it should be in the whole tract of Anti-Cavalierisme, of which this artificer should make his Mercurie, or lying Statue. The common saying is, that Dolosut versatur in generalibus. They that mean to lie, or to deceive, you shall still find them in generals; because in such cases, the conviction or discovery is more difficultie made. They tell you they have a Needle of nine pence in a Bottle of Hay, disprove them if you can. The Bishop in his former encounter, somewhat honestly (as wee heard) cited the Anti-Cavalier, p. 17. 18 &c. in his Margent, over against his charge: but here though his charge be seven times deeper, no lesse (as you have heard) then maliciously and reproachfully
to lay such things to His Majesties charge, as are generally knowne by all those that know him, to bee apparent lies and abominable slanders, yet the bare credit and reputation of his honesty, is all the proofe or testimony you have from him, of the truth thereof. Hee makes accompt (it seemes) that the credit of his honesty is as authentique, and high prized in the world, as the Scribes and Pharisees, presumed thiers was with Pilate, to whom, being demanded what accusation they brought against Christ, being so eager in their prosecution of him they returned no other answer but this; If he were not an evill doer, wee would not have delivered him unto thee. So all the accompt
〈◊〉 . 13. 13. or evidence you must looke for from the accuser of his Brethren, of those hainous matters here laid to the charge of Goodwin and Borrowghs. and others by him, is onely this; that if they had done so and so hee would not have laid it to their charge. But Sir, let me tell you one thing (which may bee worth many a two that are told you otherwise) that if you would bee believed in your accusations and charges against godly men without proofe.
div.q:
Quare peregrinum, vicinia rauca reclamat
i.
This Nation tells you with a loud consent,
That much might be if to another you went.
div.p: For in this Nation your credit in this kind is broken in pieces like a potters vessell, whereof there remaines not so much as a sheard or piece, wherewith to take, either a little fire from the hearth; or a little water out of the pit. You and men of your order, have for so long a time, and so often, accursed godly men falsely, that now your accusations only turne to a Testimony unto them, without further proofe.

As for the Author of the Soveraigne Antidote. I know him not (at least by any relation to such a writing) but that he should be NAMELESSE, is one of the Bishops profound speculations. But because his meaning in the word (I suppose) is innocent and harmelesse, wee will not make him an offender for a little Grammaticall acyrologie in speaking.

Mr. Burrowghs I well know; and verily believe his gleanings both in honesty and learning, to be better then the Prelates vintage in both. Nor hath his angry Lordship done any courtesie to speake of, to the Anti-Cavalier, in all his Discourse, except it be in joyning him with Mr. Burroughs: but in this hee hath accommodated him with the like honour, wherwith the blind man restored to sight by our Saviour, 10. 9. Was gratified by the Scribes and Pharisees, who excommunicated him, and cast him out of their society unto Christ and his Apostles. But were all the men he mentions, the namelesse Author, Goodwin, Burrowghs, and as many more as you will, were they (I say) all Angells from Heaven, yet if they doe but touch the mountaine of Episcopacie with the least finger of contempt they must be struck thorough with some Episcopall dart or other, and their names (at least) ston'd to death with the hardest & roughest accusations that the great accuser of the Brethren can furnish his executioners with, for the service But this angry piece of Episcopacy affects (as it seemes) the glory of a true Achillean Cavalier, and then his impresse must be.
div.q:
Quae libet in quemvis opprobria fingere soevus,
i.
Advanc'd in choller, fiercely to revile,
Who 'ere comes in his way, with lying stile.
div.p: I shall for (the present) onely desire this of the Ingenuous Reader, that the Anti-Cavalier may stand right and straight in his thoughts, untill his Accuser hath made good that sore charge of his against him, I meane of laying such things to His Majesties charge which himselfe and all that know him, know to be apparent lies and abominable slanders. And when this Heaven falls he makes no question but he shall have Larks enough to feast the Bishop, and make him and himselfe perfect friends.

div.head: CAP. VI. The Bishops last Encounter against the Anti-Cavalier, Wherin he chargeth him, with little lesse then justifying any Rebellion against the King, and much admires that he with his fellowes is not apprehended and transferred to the Kings Bench barre, and there arraigned &c. Examined.
div.p: THE Man by this time hath reasoned himselfe quite out of all his learning, reason, and patience into a moody cholerique and bloody passion. For sure if his wits or conscience had bin within call, he would never have made presse worke of such rotten stuffe, as hee hath spread upon the face of his 97. page the spinning whereof runs thus. Then we grow so impudent as to justifie any rebellion against our King: as in England, Goodwin and that seditious Pamphleter in opening the glorious name of the Lord of Hosts, doe but a little lesse: for which application of Gods glorious name, and abusing the holy Scriptures to such abominable transgression of Gods holy Precepts, to instigate the Subjects to warre against their Soveraigne, and to involve a whole Kingdome into a desperate distraction: I doe much admire that they are not apprehended and transferred to the Kings Bench barre to be there arraigned, and condemned to be punished according to their deserts.

I wonder a little, how the Bishop came by his simples for this Receipt. Surely hee hath good correspondence with Pluto: for we have here beaten and stamp'd together, as the principall ingredients in the composition.
div.q:
Oris Cerberei spumas, et virus Echidnae,
i.
The foamy froth of Cerberus triple chaps,
Mixt with the poyson of a female Aspe.
div.p: Onely this I must confesse, that did he meane as hee speaketh (but Episcopacie seldome dasheth his foot against this stone) in the first clause, it were an hopefull straine of ingenuity in him; for here in words, hee ingenuously rangeth himsefe, amongst those that are so impudent, as to justifie any rebellion against the King. Then we are so impudent, &c. And yet againe on the other hand, speaking this of the Parliament (which it's evident from the lines preceding that hee doth) there is a straine of impudence even in this ingenuity. For what hath he to doe to joyne himselfe with the Parliament, as one of them, when as his whole Order is spued out from thence.

Well, but the man is here in his Rhetoricalls, and wee doe him some wrong to make him speake Logique, that is, reason and truth, against his will. His meaning is plain enough, viz: to charge the Parliament of England with so much impudence, as to justifie any Rebellion against the King. It was time for the Kingdome to make the mountaine of Samaria; the Lordly Prelacy I meane) to smoake, and to force them down, like lightening from the heaven of their power, when their spirits were so farre overgrowne with pride and insolency, as to challenge the Supreme Court of Justice in the Land, with the justifying of Rebellion, nay (which is a calumny whereunto no pen lightly but a Bishops, could have bin tempted or suborned) with the justifying of any Rebellion against the King. Why, how many kinds or degrees are there of Rebellion against the King? is the Parliament, or Parliament friends, so impudent as to justifie them ALL, the worst, the fowlest, and most desperate of them ALL? He professeth admiration, that Goodwin and the seditious Pamphleter, are not apprehended and transferred to the Kings Bench to be there arraigned, and condemned to be punished according to their deserts (all which might bee done, and yet not an haire of their heads fall to the ground) but it is rather matter of double admiration, that such portentuous revilers and blasphemers of the highest powers and authority that God hath placed over them, especially without the least occasion given, should not either be recompensed with vengeance revealed from Heaven, or be made examples of the
deepest severity of the Justice of the Land, or otherwise bee dismembred and torne in pieces by the impatient rage and indignation of the people.

But let us coole a little in this heat on both sides, and then to it againe, with somewhat more moderation. You talke much in your discourse, of resisting authority, and rising up against the lawfull authority of the King, of the hainousnes of Rebellion, with the like. But all this while you transgresse the old law or rule for arguing and discourse, which is this; Omnis disputatio debet à definitione proficisci: all disputations should begin with the definition of that, which is intended for the matter of dispute. Wee doe not understand, by any thing wee find from the beginning of your discourse to the end, what you meane by the Authority of the King, or by Rebellion. It may be you are best in the darke; and the light is to you that which Iob saith it is to Thieves, as the shadow of death, Job. 24. 17. The Scripture speaketh oft of authority, and condemneth Rebellion as a grievous sinne: but what authority, or rebellion is (to my best remembrance) it defineth not. We simple and well meaning men, conceive that the laws of every state and those who are authorized by these lawes, for their interpreters in doubtfull cases, are rather to be advised with, about the nature of that authority which is lawfull & lawfully setled in every State or Kingdom respectively, and so about the nature of Rebellion, then with Divines, especially those of the chayre. The Scriptures command that justice be done on all hands and that no mans right be deteined from him: but whether this house or inheritance that happily is in question between severall pretenders, be the right of the one, or of the other, it determineth not at all: but leaveth this to be adjudged by the Lawes, or vice-Lawes (I mean the customes of the State) wherein the question falleth. In like manner, what the Authority or lawfull power (for these I judge to be much the same) of the King of England is, and so what the lawfull power of an English Parliament is, is not to be found by searching the Scriptures though never so narrowly: the English Lawes are the Oracles that must be consulted with for the knowledge and determination of these.
And so likewise it is for matter of Rebellion. And in case there ariseth any question betweeene partie and partie concerning either, which the first letter of the Law (as I may call it) is not able to determine or reconcile; then the second letter of the Law, i. the persons nominated or authorized by the Law, or at least by such a custome as is authorized by the Law for her interpretation in such cases, is to determine it. In case there be a subordniation of such persons, and the resolution of the inferiour be not yet satisfactory, recourse must be had to the supreame in whose award there lies a necessity upon both sides and parties to acquiesce and rest, there being no possiblity of any farther appeale, but unto God himselfe. And what the resolution of the Supreme Judicatorie appointed or countenanced by the Law, in such cases of difference or question shall be is to be look'd upon & judged as the resolution of the law it self, yea of the known law of the Kingdom.

If this chain will hold (and I believed that all the force and strength of all the Episcopall learning in the land will not be able to breake the weakest linke of it) then look to your selfe, least you and your fellow Cavaliers, be in due time drawn by it to the Kings Bench barre you speak of, to be there arraigned and condemned to be punished according to your deserts; Which (I feare would be found another manner of punishment, then what either the Anti-Cavalier, or Pamphleter you speake of have deserved. For there is no law of the Kingdom better known, then that the high Court of Parliament is the Supreame Judicatory of all Questions and disputes in law, against, and from whom there lieth no appeale to any other Judge or Judicatory but onely to another of the same, I meane another Parliament. And therefore it is they, not you, that must determine and define, what lawfull authority, and what Rebellion is in England. Therefore Sir, you are fallen into the premunire of the old Proverb, Sutor ultra crepidam having plaid the Cobler beyond your Last, to Arraigne and condemn at your pleasure, for resisting lawfull Authority, and for Rebellion, which are crimes of another cognizance; and from which they, to whom the cognizance and Judicature of such matters properly belong have not only acquitted the persons by you arraigned and condemned, but have laid your waller upon your owne neck, and have concluded, stop the Thiefe, to be the Thiefe himself.

And whereas you hope to be relieved by the Kings absence from the Parliament, and think their resolutions and determinations without him to be invalid and insufficient, you must know that this is but to few fig leaves together to cover your nakednesse. For,
1o. This being a case and question in law, what if the Parliament it self should give sentence against you? Your fig leaves are gone.

2o. Those that understand the Laws of the Kingdome better then either you or I wil tel you, that though the King may be personally absent from the Parliament, ( See the Treatise intituled, the disloyalty and Treachery of Papists to their Soveraignes, &c. p. 21. & p. 41. &c.) yet legally he cannot. The King (say they) in judgment of law, is ever legally present, in, and with his Parliament when they sit, wherever his person is: and his Royall legall will (of which alone the law takes notice) is ever presumed to concurre with his greatest counsell the Parliament, &c. As in all other Courts of Iustice, all proceedings are entred coram Rege, though the King never yet sate personally in any of them, as he hath oft times done in this Parliament. So that you cleerly see, that neither the Kings absence from the Parliament, nor yet his refusing to give his personall consent to their votes and determinations, will any waies acquit you, from being both a Traytor and Rebell, in case the Parliament shall adjudge you either.

3o. And lastly, in case the authority of Parliament, still including (as we heard) the Royall legall will, and consent of the King, bee found and proved, to be the Supream authority, or highest power in the Land, let Gr. Williams the Lord Bishop of Ossory, and all the Cavaliering Bishops and all co-operating Papists, and others who oppose the Parliament, know, that they, and none other but they are the men, who resist the higher powers, & consequently shall receive to themselves that damnation, which the Apostle threatneth, Rom. 13. 2. except they repent.

And if the said Gr: Williams would not have it thought or believed, that the authority of Parliament, is their highest authority and power in the Land, and consequently that himself and his Copes-mates are Rebells, and the men that have involved the whole Kingdom into a distraction, let him acquit himself like a man, and substantially answer, those fourteen Arguments, which are laid down and argued at large to prove it, by the Author of the Discourse formerly mentioned, entituled: The Treacherie and disloyaltie of Papists to their Soveraigns in Doctrine and practise, &c. from p. 17. of the said Discourse to the end.

When the Bishop hath honestly, and with currant money amongst understanding men, paid this reckoning, it is like the Anti-Cavalier shall be willing to trade further with him upon a new score. But in the meane time, I professe ingenuously, that
I know not how to help it, but that he and his, must be look'd upon, as guilty of those hainous crimes, wherwith they so fiercely charge their innocent adversaries, I meane, Rebellion and resisting lawfull authority.

And whereas, in this encounter, hee layeth it to the charge of the Anti-Cavalier, that: he abuseth the Scripture; I answer, that all his guilt in this kind lyeth in his being accused. When his accuser shall permute his effeminate affirmations for Masculine argumentations, and his raylings for reasonings, he shall bee willing to addresse himselfe, either to a faire and thorow purgation of himselfe, or to an humble acknowledgment of his misprissions in this kind. But howsoever,

l.hi: Quis tulerit Gracchos de seditious querentes.

lg.l: Who can indure to heare, without disdaine,
The Gracchi of sedition to complaine.

div.p:
What? Bishops complaine of men for abusing the Scriptures? When as (alasse) the abuse of Scripture is the foundation of their thrones. It is not by the milk, but by the blood of the Scriptures that this order of men is nourished and kept alive in the World. And as for this Episcopal blade, which we have now in hand, it is hard to say, whether he hath cited, or abused, more Scriptures in his Grand Rebellion. Certaine I am that in the generall, hee hath abused, tot quot, as many as he hath cited: for he hath ingaged them all against the Parliament, and Parliamentary proceedings, i. against the advancement of Gods glory in a peaceable and legall way of reformation. It were an endlesse task to grapple with him, about the sense and interpretation, of all the particular texts of Scripture, upon which he hath laid violent and abusive hands, in this discourse, There are six together cited, p. 49. of his discourse, all which we have already proved, to be meerly abused and mistaken by him. How he hath abused that Scripture, Rom. 13. 1, 2. Let every soule bee subiect to the higher power: and whosoever resisteth, resisteth the ordinance of God, by his consecration of it, for the chiefe Sanctuary of himselfe and his fellow Cavaliers, sufficiently appeareth by what hath bin lately argued in this Chapter. In severall places, he toucheth at, Psal. 105. 15. Touch not mine anointed, to prove all Kings the anointed of the Lord, and immediately invested with their power and authority from him. Whereas it's evident from the former verse, yea, and from the scope and carriage of the whole Psalm, that this
was not spoken to any people concerning Kings, as if they were the Lords anointed, that might not be touch'd: but unto Kings themselves concerning a people (the people indeed of God) as being his anointed ones, whom it concerned even Kings themselves not to touch in any way of injustice or offence. For in the very immediately preceding, he had said: Hee suffered no man to them wrong: yea, he reproved Kings for their Sakes. Saying, Touch not mine anointed, &c.

But this sence of this Scripture hath of late, bin largely and substantially vindicated by a more learned pen. I shall (for the present) leave his warie Reader to his own observation, for more Scriptures abused by him.

And for conclusion. I shall only desire my Reader, to take knowledge of the most bitter, envenomed, and bloody spirit of the man, who finds himselfe aggrieved (even to admiration) that others are not affected with the same bloody passion with him) that the Anti-Cavalier, and the Seditious Pamphleter (seditiously so called) are not apprehended, and arraigned at the Kings Bench Barre, for abusing the Scriptures to instigate Subjects to Warre against their Soveraigne, that is, for perswading men by the Scriptures, to performe both to King and Kingdome such a service, as the wit of this mans malice know's not how to traduce under a more plausible Name, then of an instigating Subjects to war against their Soveraign.

Suppose it were certainly knowne, that a Roche, Miter, pall, and Tippet did much endanger the life or soule of the Bishop that weares them, though the Bishop himselfe conceited otherwise, and thought himselfe the braver man and so much the neerer Heaven for having such caparisons upon him; doth he that seekes to devest him of these dangerous accoutrements, though against his will, deserve to be called his enemie, or to be thought a man that either wish'd or sough't to do him harme? For my part in case a Bishop should be mistaken in any thing that relates unto me, and should conceive that to be evill and dangerous unto me, which yet in truth is not, and upon this supposition, should do his best to separate between me and the supposed evill; well might I judge him to be a man of no profound reach; but deem him an enemy, I thinke I should not, certain I am, that I should have no sufficient ground of such an expression of his towards me, so to doe. I have formerly as farre as by words I well know how to do, vindicated not the innocencie and loyaltie onely, but the affectionatenesse likewise of my intentions for good towards his Majesty: of this man will take Satans occupation out of his hand, and make me like himselfe, I meane malignant, whether I will, or no; his accusation will yet beare it's own charges, and what it takes from me (for the (present) before men, it will hereafter restore and adde unto me double before God. And so fare-well Gr. Williams, L. Bishop of Ossory, or whoever thou art, that facest the world, and out-facest the truth, under this title.

div.head: ERRATA.
div.p: PAg. 12. l. 12. for on, r. one. p. 12. l, 30. for affirme, r. assume, p. 15. l. 15. for Estate, r. State. p. 16. l. 26. for: r. ib. l. 31. for scrase, r. scarce. p. 27. l. 25: for his, r. their. p. 18. l. 17. for on, r, one. p. 21. l. ult. for modest, r. modesty. p. 21. l. 10. dele or. p. 22. l. 22. for dencein r, dence in, p. 24. l. 22. for aed, r. ed. l. 23. for man, r. a man. p. 25. l. 37, for his, r. this. p. 27. l. 12. for 2o. r. 1o. l. 24 for and, r. a. p. 38 l. 19. for annimate, r. animate. l. ult. for one, r. on. p. 39. l. 15. for incence. r. incense. p. 41. l. 22, dele, a. p. 45. l. 25. dele,; p. 47. l, 1. for precise r. and precise. l. 16. for judgment, r. indictment. l. 33. for times, r. terms. p. 51. l. 26. dele un, p. 53 l. 19. for the, r. then the. p. 56. l. 16. for had; r. had not l. 30. for cursed, r. cused. p. 59 l 2 for his, r. her, l. 18. for,; r.) p. 62. l. 29. for their, r. the. p. 64 l. 6. for very, r. verse. l. 7. for to. r. to doe.
There are diverse others mispointings with some mispellings. Wherein the Reader is desired to befriend the Corrector with his paines and pardon.
